(c)  Any person who is not of good moral character; 
(d)  Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsection (a), (b) or (c) has a proprietary, equitable or credit interest, or in which such a person is active or employed; 
(e)  Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (a), (b) or (c) is an officer, director, or employee, whether compensated or not; 
(f)  Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (a), (b) or (c) is to participate in the management or operation of a raffle as defined in this Act. 
(Prior code § 32.17(c)) 
(Ord. No. 09-O-24, § 1, 10-5-2009) 
5.44.040 - Limitations. 
    The aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise awarded by a licensee in a single raffle under this chapter and in accordance with applicable state law is limited to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00); the maximum retail value of each prize awarded by a licensee in a single raffle is limited to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). The maximum price which may be charged for each raffle chance issued or sold is limited to one hundred dollars ($100.00), and the maximum number of days during which chances may be issued or sold is limited to three hundred sixty-five (365) days. 
(Prior code § 32.17(d)) 
(Ord. No. 09-O-24, § 1, 10-5-2009; Ord. No. 12-O-20, § 1, 9-17-2012) 
5.44.050 - Fees. 
    Fees for such a license to conduct a raffle or a lottery shall be ten dollars ($10.00). Fees for the license cannot be waived. 
(Prior code § 32.17(e)) 
(Ord. No. 09-O-24, § 1, 10-5-2009) 
5.44.060 - Approval. 
    The village clerk shall within thirty (30) days evaluate and either approve or disapprove of said application. An approved application for a license shall constitute the license for the conduct of the raffle applied for by the applicant. 
(Prior code § 32.17(f)) 
(Ord. No. 09-O-24, § 1, 10-5-2009) 
5.44.070 - Conduct of raffles. 
    The conducting of raffles is subject to the following restrictions: 
A.  Proceeds. The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game. 
B.  Participation in Management. No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization may participate in the management or operation of the raffle. 
C.  Remuneration. No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating in the management or operation of the raffle. 
D.  Premises. A licensee may rent premises on which to determine the winning chance or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed under this chapter. 
E.  Locations. Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified on the license and winning chances may be determined only at those locations specified on the license. 
F.  Age. No person under the age of eighteen (18) years may participate in the conducting of raffles or chances. A person under the age of eighteen (18) years may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when accompanied by his or her parent or guardian. 
(Prior code § 32.17(g)) 
(Ord. No. 09-O-24, § 1, 10-5-2009) 
5.44.080 - Records. 
A.  Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the purchased item or service or other reason for the deduction, and the recipient. The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount and date of payment. 
B.  Gross receipts from the operation of raffle programs shall be segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization pursuant to license therefor issued by the Department of Revenue of the State of Illinois, and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have separate records of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same person who accounts for other revenues of the organization. 
C.  Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall report promptly after the conclusion of each raffle to its membership, and to the Village of Round Lake, its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from raffles, and the distribution of net proceeds itemized as required in this section. 
D.  Records required by this section shall be preserved for three years, and organizations shall make available their records relating to operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places. 
(Prior code § 32.17(h)) 
(Ord. No. 09-O-24, § 1, 10-5-2009) 
5.44.090 - Manager's bond. 
    All operation and conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of a single raffle manager designated by the organization. The manager shall give a fidelity bond, in an amount equal to the aggregate value of the prize(s) to be awarded, in favor of the licensee and conditioned upon the manager's honesty in the performance of his/her duties. Terms of the bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to the licensing authority not less than thirty (30) days prior to its cancellation. The bond requirement may be waived only by unanimous vote of the members of the licensed organization. In such case, the waiver of the fidelity bond shall be stated on the license when issued. 
(Editorially amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 32.17(i)) 
(Ord. No. 09-O-24, § 1, 10-5-2009) 
Chapter 5.48 - SIGN BUSINESSES 
Sections: 

5.48.010 - License and insurance. 
    No person shall engage in the business of erecting signs without a license therefor. An applicant for such license shall file with the village clerk a good and sufficient certificate of insurance evidencing the fact that the applicant is insured for the period for which the application is made for public liability in the minimum amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per person, three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) per accident and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage. Such certificate of insurance shall be attached to the application and placed on file with the village clerk. In the event the village clerk or the municipal authorities are notified that the insurance policy has been cancelled, then the license shall forthwith be revoked effective the date of the cancellation of the insurance policy. 
(Prior code § 28.07) 
Chapter 5.52 - TAXICABS 
Sections: 

5.52.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Licensee" means every person or corporation applying for and obtaining a license hereunder covering one or more licensed taxicabs which are operated within the village. 
    "Registered operator" means every person registering hereunder and driving or operating a licensed taxicab within the village. 
    "Taxicab" means any vehicle used to carry less than ten (10) passengers for hire but not operating on a fixed route. 
(Prior code § 35.01) 
5.52.020 - License and registration required-Fees. 
A.  License Requirements. 
1.  It is unlawful for any person or corporation to engage in the business of operating a taxicab within the village without first having obtained a license hereunder. 
2.  Applications for licenses to engage in the business of operating a taxicab within the village shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall state thereon the name of the applicant, the address of the applicant's place of business and the number of taxicabs to be operated within the village and covered by the license. With respect to each taxicab, it shall state the make, model, year, color, serial number or motor number, state of Illinois license plate number and permanently assigned taxicab identification number, if applicant has more than one taxicab. If the applicant is a corporation, the names and addresses of the president and secretary thereof shall be stated on the application. 
    In addition the applicant shall state his or her social security number, driver's license number and dates and places that the applicant has previously applied for a taxicab license and whether applicant has ever been denied such license; applicant shall further furnish proof of required insurance or an appropriate letter of commitment indicating that required insurance is available to applicant; applicant shall further state any criminal, quasi-criminal or civil court actions pending or brought against applicant within the last five years arising out of or related to applicant's use or ownership of a motor vehicle; applicant shall further furnish not less than three credit references and not less than two personal references. 
    Applicant's failure to provide the aforesaid information or applicant's furnishing of materially false or misleading information shall result in applicant's denial of license; lack of history or lack of financial responsibility or history of serious and material criminal or traffic violations on the part of applicant or employees of applicant shall result in applicant's denial of license. 
3.  Each application for a license shall be accompanied by the payment of the annual fee in the amount of sixty dollars ($60.00) for each taxicab to be operated within the village and covered by the license. In the event the license is not issued, the fee shall be returned to the applicant. 
B.  Registration Requirements. 
1.  It is unlawful for any person to drive or operate a taxicab within the village without first having registered as an operator hereunder. 
2.  Registrations to drive or operate a taxicab within the village shall be made in writing to the village clerk and shall state thereon the name, address, telephone number, sex, state of Illinois motor vehicle operator's license number and social security number of the registrant, as well as a physical description of the registrant, including approximate height, weight and color of hair and eyes. The registration shall be accompanied by two photographs of the registrant, approximate size two inches by two inches taken within the last sixty (60) days, showing the head and shoulders of the registrant in a clear and distinguishable manner. 
3.  Each registration shall be accompanied by the payment of an annual fee of ten dollars ($10.00). In the event that the registration is rejected, the fee shall be returned to the registrant. False registration, or history of serious and material criminal or traffic violations shall result in rejection of registration. 
C.  Expiration of Licenses and Registrations. All such licenses and registrations shall expire on April 30th of each year. All licensees shall reapply for and obtain a new license, and all registered operators shall reregister for each year beginning May 1st and ending April 30th. 
(Prior code § 35.02) 
5.52.030 - Identification tags or stickers. 
    At the time each license is issued by the village clerk, the licensee shall also receive a tag or sticker for each of the taxicabs covered by the license. Such tag or sticker shall be displayed in a prominent place on each taxicab covered by the license while it is used, and may be transferred by the licensee to any taxicab which the licensee puts into service to replace one withdrawn from service, provided the licensee notifies the village clerk in writing prior thereto of the make, model, year, color, serial number or motor number, state license plate number and permanently assigned taxicab identification number of the replacement taxicab as well as of the taxicab being replaced. 
(Prior code § 35.03) 
5.52.040 - Vehicle requirements. 
    No taxicab shall be operated within the village unless it bears duly issued state of Illinois license plates. If a taxi company has its home base in the village, the taxicabs must also secure village vehicle licenses. All taxicabs shall be maintained in good operating condition for safe, clean and comfortable service and shall be equipped with proper brakes, lights, tires, horn, muffler, rear vision mirror and windshield wipers, all in good condition. 
    Each licensee shall cause an annual inspection to be made at an Illinois State Safety Lane of each taxicab operated within the village and covered by the license issued to such licensee, and shall obtain a valid certificate showing that each such taxicab has passed such inspection. Each application for a licensee shall be accompanied by such a valid certificate for the current year with respect to each taxicab to be covered by the license being applied for. 
    If a licensee has more than one taxicab operated within the village and covered by the license issued to such licensee, each taxicab shall be permanently assigned a different taxicab identification number by such licensee and such number, together with the name of the licensee, shall appear on each side of such taxicab in letters not less than two inches high. 
    Every taxicab shall be operated regularly to the extent reasonably necessary to meet the public demand service. 
    All vehicles used for taxicabs must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and must be properly equipped with brakes, lights and warning signals. The name of the owner of such vehicle shall be printed or painted in a prominent place on both sides of the vehicle in letters at least two inches high, and if any licensee operates more than one such vehicle, each such vehicle shall be uniform in color and printing and shall be numbered with figures not less than two inches high, but no two vehicles operated by the same licensee shall bear the same number. No license shall be issued for the operation of any taxicab until the vehicle has been carefully inspected under the direction of the chief of police and found to be in a safe condition for the transportation of passengers, clean, and in a sanitary condition and of good appearance and properly painted. 
(Prior code § 35.04) 
5.52.050 - Insurance requirements. 
    Notwithstanding the requirements of any law or statute for the filing of bonds and policies of insurance against liability for injury to or death of any person or for damage of property by any person operating any public passenger vehicle, each licensee shall carry public liability and property damage insurance or give surety bond to secure payment of any loss or damage resulting from any occurrence arising out of or caused by the operation or use of any of the licensee's taxicabs covering each taxicab for the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage, one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injuries to or death of any one person, and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injuries in any one accident. The insurance or surety company issuing such insurance policy or surety bond shall be satisfactory to the village's license committee. 
    Each application for a license shall be accompanied by a valid certificate from such insurance or surety company for the current year evidencing the issuance of such insurance policy or security bond with respect to all of the taxicabs to be covered by the license applied for. 
(Prior code § 35.05) 
5.52.060 - Driver and operator requirements. 
A.  All drivers and operators of taxicabs licensed in the village shall have a valid current Illinois State motor vehicle operator's license and shall register as an operator as required in Section 5.52.020. 
B.  No registered operator shall drive or operate a taxicab within the village which is not covered by a license hereunder. No licensee shall permit a taxicab covered by a license hereunder to be driven or operated within the village by a person who is not a registered operator hereunder. 
C.  No registered operator shall be on duty as a driver or operator for more than sixteen (16) hours of any twenty-four (24) consecutive hours and no licensee shall permit any registered operator to be on duty for more than sixteen (16) hours out of every twenty-four (24) consecutive hours. 
D.  No registered operator, while on duty, shall drink any intoxicating liquor or use any profane or obscene language, or shout or call to prospective passengers or to disturb the peace in any way. 
E.  Every registered operator shall obey all traffic rules and regulations established by Illinois law or village ordinances while driving or operating a taxicab within the village. 
(Prior code § 35.06) 
5.52.070 - Unlawful use. 
    It is unlawful to knowingly permit any taxicab to be used in the perpetration of any felony or misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 35.07) 
5.52.080 - Passengers. 
    No registered operator shall refuse to accept as a passenger any person who seeks to use the taxicab being driven or operated by such registered operator, provided such person is not intoxicated and conducts himself or herself in an orderly manner. No person shall be admitted to a taxicab occupied by a passenger without the consent of the passenger. Every passenger shall be taken to his or her destination by the most direct available route from the place where the passenger entered the cab. Upon paying the fare, and upon request, each passenger shall be given a receipt showing the amount so paid and the name of the licensee and registered operator of the taxicab, together with the permanently assigned identification number of the taxicab, if such licensee has more than one taxicab. 
    It is unlawful for a passenger to refuse or fail to pay the lawful taxicab fare at the termination of the trip. 
    No passenger shall attempt to have baggage or trunks carried on the outside of the taxicab and no registered operator shall permit baggage or trunks to be carried on the outside of the taxicab. 
(Prior code § 35.08) 
5.52.090 - Meters. 
    No taxicab covered by a license hereunder shall be operated unless it is equipped with a sealed meter in good condition to record the amount to be charged on each trip, which amount shall be shown in figures visible to the passenger. Each such meter shall have a lever known as a "flag" which, when put into a down position will start such meter recording. Such lever or flag shall be in the down position and such meter shall be recording for the duration of all trips. 
    It shall be the duty of every person owning, controlling or operating any taxicab under a general taxicab license, to deliver either the taxicab together with the taximeter or the taximeter detached therefrom to the chief of police upon demand for testing. Any such person may be present or represented at the time such test is made. Every taximeter shall be tested to determine the accuracy of its recording mechanism with respect to distance traveled either by running the taxicab to which it is attached over a course a standard mile in length or by a mechanical test. In the event the taximeter is found defective, the same cannot be used until it has been repaired and the accuracy of its recording mechanism restored. 
(Prior code § 35.09) 
5.52.100 - Rates of fare. 
    All rates of fare must be submitted on the application for license to operate within the village. The rates must be approved by the license committee and be maintained on file in the clerk's office. The rates must also be prominently displayed in the cab for the benefit of all passengers. Notice must also be given to passengers that said rates can be verified by the village clerk's office. The license committee must approve any change in rates. 
    Licensees may charge passengers one and one-half times the amount shown on the meter for trips starting or finishing within the village and ending or beginning outside the village in areas where the licensee's rates of fare are not established by another unit of local government, provided that the passenger is informed thereof prior to the commencement of the trip. 
    No licensee or registered operator shall charge, collect or receive greater or lesser rates of fare for use of taxicabs than those approved by the license committee and on file in the clerk's office, except that any licensee may file a written statement with the village clerk setting forth reasonable classifications of passengers to whom a discount shall be given and the amount of the discount. 
    Such discounts may be given only to those passengers falling within such reasonable classifications. Such classifications of passengers to whom a discount shall be given may be reviewed by the corporate authorities from time to time and declared invalid if they do not appear to be reasonable. 
    The licensee may withdraw such written statement setting forth reasonable classifications of passengers to whom a discount shall be given by filing a written request with the village clerk at least ten (10) days prior to the effective date thereof and may amend or modify such reasonable classifications, and/or the amount of such discounts, by filing a written statement to that effect with the village clerk at least ten (10) days prior to the effective date thereof. 
(Prior code § 35.10) 
5.52.110 - Existing licensees. 
    All currently issued licenses to engage in the business of operating taxicabs within the village shall remain in effect after the adoption of this chapter until April 30, 1979, when they shall expire. The village clerk shall issue license to each of such licensees beginning May 1, 1979, and from year to year thereafter covering the number of taxicabs presently being operated by each such licensee, upon proper application being made as provided hereunder, unless such license has theretofore been revoked or modified in accordance herewith. The village clerk shall not issue licenses to other persons or corporations unless authorized so to do by the corporate authorities of the village as provided herein. 
    All currently issued licenses to drivers of taxicabs shall also remain in effect after the adoption of this chapter until April 30, 1979, when they shall expire after which time each driver of a taxicab shall be registered as required herein. 
(Prior code § 35.11) 
5.52.120 - Inspection of taxicabs-Records. 
    Each licensee shall permit duly authorized representatives designated by the mayor or corporate authorities of the village to, at any reasonable time or times, inspect all taxicabs including the meters attached thereto, operated within the village and covered by a license hereunder and any and all books and records of all property, operations, receipts and disbursements relating to business done within the village by such licensee for information as to the character and quality of the licensee's service, the adequacy of the number of taxicabs operating within the village to meet the demand for service and whether the established or any proposed rates of fare and other charges for taxicab service are fair and reasonable. 
(Prior code § 35.12) 
5.52.130 - Revocation or modification of licenses. 
    If any licensee violates the provisions of this chapter or any Illinois State law or other village ordinance relating to the operation of taxicabs or motor vehicles within the village, the village board may revoke the license issued to such licensee by giving written notice thereof to such licensee with the reason or reasons for the revocation, in which event such licensee shall not permit any taxicabs covered by the license revoked to be operated within the village until or unless such license is restored by the corporate authorities. 
    If any or all of the taxicabs covered by a license hereunder are not operated for a period of six or more consecutive days, the license committee may modify the license so as to delete the taxicab or taxicabs which are not in operation by giving a written notice thereof to the licensee to which such license is issued, in which event the taxicab or taxicabs so deleted may not be operated within the village until or unless the deletion is rescinded by the license committee or the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Prior code § 35.13) 
5.52.140 - Conditions of license. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as the granting of a vested or exclusive right to any licensee to engage in the business of operating taxicabs within the village. Every license hereunder shall be regarded only as a privilege which is afforded the person or corporation to whom it is issued, and which may be modified, suspended, revoked, canceled, invalidated or otherwise voided by the corporate authorities at any time hereafter. 
(Prior code § 35.14) 
5.52.150 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense; shall be deemed committed for each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Editorially amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 35.15) 
Chapter 5.56 - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND VENDORS 
Sections: 

5.56.010 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for an exhibitor, transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor as defined in Section 5.56.020 to engage in such business within the village without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 32.15(a)) 
5.56.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, an "exhibitor," "transient merchant," "itinerant merchant" or "itinerant vendor" is defined as any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of the village or not, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and merchandise within the village, and who, in furtherance of such purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad box car, or boat, public room in hotels, lodging houses, apartments, shops, or any street, alley, or other place within the village, for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction; provided, that such definition shall not be construed to include any person, firm or corporation who, while occupying such temporary location, does not sell from stock, but exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future delivery only. The person, firm or corporation so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the provisions of this chapter merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as a part of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
(Prior code § 32.15(b)) 
5.56.030 - Application. 
    Applicants for license under this chapter, whether a person, firm or corporation, shall file a written sworn application signed by the applicant, if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the president if a corporation, with the village clerk, showing: 
A.  The name or names of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the village; the local address or addresses of such person or persons while engaged in such business; the permanent address or addresses of such person or persons; the capacity in which such person or persons will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise); the name and address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the business will be carried on, if any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is incorporated; 
B.  The fingerprints of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business or in lieu thereof, at least three letters of recommendation from reliable property owners in the county of Lake, Illinois, certifying as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or other evidence which establishes to the satisfaction of the mayor the good character and business responsibility of such person or persons; 
C.  The place or places in the village where it is proposed to carry on applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that the business shall be conducted; 
D.  The place or places, other than the permanent place of business of the applicant where applicant within the six months next preceding the date of the application conducted a transient business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address of any building or office in which such business was conducted; 
E.  A statement of the nature, character and quality of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold or offered for sale by applicant in the village; 
F.  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or proposed to be done in order to attract customers; 
G.  Whether or not the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's business have been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor; 
H.  Such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's business or the method or plan of doing such business as the village clerk may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this chapter in the protection of the public good. 
(Prior code § 32.15(c)) 
5.56.040 - Investigation and issuance. 
    Upon receipt of such application, the village clerk shall cause such investigation of such person's or persons' business responsibility or moral character to be made as the clerk deems necessary to the protection of the public good. If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character and business responsibility are found to be unsatisfactory, the application shall be denied. If, as a result of the investigation, the character and business reputation appear to be satisfactory, the village clerk shall so certify in writing, and a license shall be issued by the village clerk. The village clerk shall keep a full record in his or her office of all licenses issued. Such license shall contain the number of the license, the date the same is issued, the nature of the business authorized to be carried on, the amount of the license fee paid, the expiration date of the license, the place where the business may be carried on under the license, and the name or names of the person or persons authorized to carry on the same. 
(Prior code § 32.15(d)) 
5.56.050 - Bond. 
    Before any license, as provided by this chapter, shall be issued for engaging in a transient or itinerant business as defined in Section 5.56.020 in the village, such applicant shall file with the village clerk a surety bond running to the village in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) executed by the applicant, as principal, and two sureties upon which service of process may be made in the state of Illinois; or in lieu of a surety bond, a cash bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), the bond to be approved by the village attorney, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all of the provisions of the ordinances of the village and the statutes of the state of Illinois, regulating and concerning the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of such ordinances or statutes, or any of them, together with all judgments and costs that may be recovered against him or her by any person or persons for damage growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with such applicant, whether the misrepresentations or deceptions were made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares and merchandise sold or any part thereof. Action on the bond may be brought in the name of the village to the use of the aggrieved person. Such bond must be approved by the village attorney, both as to form, and as to the responsibility of the sureties thereon. 
(Prior code § 32.15(e)) 
5.56.060 - Service of process. 
    Before any license as provided in this chapter shall be issued for engaging in business as an itinerant merchant, as defined in this chapter, in the village, such applicant shall file with the village clerk an instrument nominating and appointing the village clerk, or the person performing the duties of such position, his or her true and lawful agent with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and on behalf of the applicant in respect to any matters connected with or arising out of the business transacted under the license and the bond given as required by Section 5.56.050, or for the performance of the conditions of the bond or for any breach thereof, which instrument shall also contain recitals to the effect that the applicant for the license consents and agrees that service of any notice or process may be made upon the agent, and when so made shall be taken and held to be as valid as if personally served upon the person or persons applying for the license under this chapter, according to the law of this or any other state, and waiving all claim or right of error by reason of such acknowledgment of service or manner of service. Immediately upon service of process upon the village clerk, as provided in this chapter, the village clerk shall send to the licensee at his or her last known address, by registered mail, a copy of the process. 
(Prior code § 32.15(f)) 
5.56.070 - Exhibition of license. 
    The license issued under this chapter shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named therein. In the event that such person or persons applying for the license shall desire to do business in more than one place within the village, separate licenses may be issued for each place of business, and shall be posted conspicuously in each place of business. 
(Prior code § 32.15(g)) 
5.56.080 - Fees. 
A.  Licensees under this chapter shall pay a minimum fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per year, but in addition pay to the village weekly as hereinafter designated, the sum of five percent of weekly sales which shall be totally refunded to the licensee upon proof being exhibited to the village clerk that the state and municipal retailers occupational tax has been paid to the state of Illinois. The evidence or proof required shall be a release from the department of revenue to the licensee for the period designated. In the event the proof is not furnished within six months from the end of the sale period or the date of the deposit, whichever is later, then the amount so deposited shall be relinquished to the village as and for an additional license fee. 
B.  Every person conducting a business licensed under this chapter shall, on the first business day of each week, and upon discontinuance of business in the village, present to the village clerk at the clerk's office, a verified statement showing the total sales made during the preceding week and shall pay to the village the amount of license fee hereinbefore provided, for sales made during the previous week. The village clerk and any other officer designated by him or her shall have power and authority to enter any store, building, or any other place in which such temporary business may be conducted at any time during business hours for ascertaining the amount of sales made and shall at all times have access to the books of such business. 
(Prior code § 32.15(h)) 
5.56.090 - Transfer. 
    No license shall be transferred without written consent from the mayor as evidenced by an endorsement on the face of the license by the village clerk showing to whom the license is transferred and the date of the transfer. 
(Prior code § 32.15(i)) 
5.56.100 - Loud noises and speaking devices. 
    No licensee under this chapter, nor anyone in his or her behalf, shall shout, make any outcry. blow a horn, ring a bell or use any other sound device including any loud speaking radio or amplifying system upon any of the streets, alleys, parks or other public places of the village or upon any private premises in the village where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom capable of being plainly heard upon the streets, avenues, alleys or parks or other public places, for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods, wares or merchandise which such licensee proposes to sell. 
(Prior code § 32.15(j)) 
5.56.110 - Duty of police to enforce. 
    It shall be the duty of the police officers of the village to examine all places of business and persons in their respective territories subject to the provisions of this chapter, to determine if this chapter has been complied with and to enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Prior code § 32.15(k)) 
5.56.120 - Records. 
    The village clerk shall deposit the record of fingerprints of licensee, together with a license number, with the chief of police; the chief of police shall report to the village clerk any complaints against any person licensed under the provisions of this chapter and any conviction for violation of this chapter; the village clerk shall keep a record of all such licenses and of such complaints and violations. 
(Prior code § 32.15(l)) 
5.56.130 - Revocation of license. 
    The permits and licenses issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked by the mayor of the village, after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
A.  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; 
B.  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the selling of goods, wares or merchandise; 
C.  Any violation of this chapter; 
D.  Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
E.  Conducting the business licensed under this chapter in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(Prior code § 32.15(m)) 
5.56.140 - Hearing on revocation of license. 
    Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee, at his last known address, at least four days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Prior code § 32.15(n)) 
5.56.150 - Appeal. 
    Any person aggrieved by the decision of the village clerk in regard to the denial of application for license as provided for in Section 5.56.040 or in connection with the revocation of a license as provided for in Section 5.56.130, shall have the right to appeal to the board of trustees of the village. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the board of trustees within fourteen (14) days after notice of the decision by the village clerk has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal. The board of trustees shall set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to such person in the same manner as provided in Section 5.56.140 for notice of hearing on revocation. The order of the board of trustees on such appeal shall be final. 
(Prior code § 32.15(o)) 
5.56.160 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Editorially amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 32.15(p)) 
Chapter 5.60 - OUTDOOR SEATING AND SIDEWALK CAFÉS 
Sections: 

5.60.010 - License required. 
    No person, partnership, firm, corporation or entity shall operate any outdoor seating or sidewalk café area within the village without a license for the same having first been issued by the village. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-15, § 1, 6-6-2011) 
5.60.020 - Definitions. 
A.  Sidewalk café means the use of any part of any public sidewalk or property within the village by any business to provide or serve either any food or any beverage, or both, or as a seating or waiting area. 
B.  Outdoor seating means the use of any private property that is reserved for a setback by any business to provide or serve either any food or any beverage, or both, or as a seating or waiting area. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-15, § 1, 6-6-2011) 
5.60.030 - Eligibility; application for license; fee. 
A.  A sidewalk café license or outdoor seating license shall be granted only to the operator of a business in good standing. 
B.  An application for sidewalk café licenses or outdoor seating licenses shall be on a form provided by the village clerk, which shall be filled out in its entirety, truthfully and accurately. The following shall also be provided by the applicant: 
1.  A copy of a valid business license and liquor license, if applicable. 
2.  The annual license fee. 
3.  A site plan indicating the setbacks from all property lines for the outdoor table or seating area when the seating area is located on commercial property and not a sidewalk café. Setbacks for the zoning district where the use is located shall be labeled and shown on the site plan for information. The site plan for sidewalk cafés should include all dimensions regarding the size and location on the sidewalk. 
4.  A seating plan along with the proposed surface area for the facility. The surface area for the facility shall be a hard surface area. 
5.  A lighting plan for the sidewalk cafe or outdoor seating area. Illumination must be compatible with adjacent uses. 
6.  The proposed hours of operation for the outdoor area. 
7.  A refuse disposal plan. At a minimum, the plan should indicate the type and locations of refuse receptacles and the method for maintaining the area. If the plan provides for customers to clean-up after themselves, then a specified periodic cleaning schedule by employees must also be provided. 
8.  A storage plan for outdoor seating areas. At a minimum, this plan shall indicate where any tables, seating, umbrellas or similar furniture or facilities will be stored during times of the year when the outdoor area may not be in use. 
9.  Detailed plans of any roof or canopy structures proposed to be used. 
10.  Any business that will be serving liquor must provide a three-foot high barrier around the seating area. 
11.  Catalog cut sheets shall be provided for the tables, chairs, benches, receptacles and any umbrellas. 
C.  The annual license fee for an outdoor seating license and sidewalk café license shall be: 
1.  One hundred dollars ($100.00) for first time applications. 
2.  Fifty dollars ($50.00) for annual renewals provided that no changes to the initial plan have been requested. Such requests shall be treated as first time applications. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-15, § 1, 6-6-2011; Ord. No. 18-O-23, § 1, 6-18-2018) 
5.60.040 - License requirements. 
A.  Issuance and continued enjoyment of outdoor seating and sidewalk café license shall be conditioned on the following: 
1.  The licensee shall comply with all applicable federal, state, and village laws and regulations, and operation of the outdoor seating area and sidewalk cafe shall not be detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare of persons residing or working in the vicinity. 
2.  Operation shall not be permitted between the hours of ten p.m. and six a.m. 
3.  Outdoor storage of any materials, food or beverages is not permitted. 
4.  The sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages in the outdoor seating area and sidewalk café shall be restricted by the liquor license governing the business. No alcoholic beverages may be removed from the outdoor seating area and sidewalk café, except to the interior of the business. 
5.  No fire exit, fire escape or other required ingress or egress shall be obstructed by the outdoor seating area and sidewalk café. 
6.  Smoking shall not be permitted within the outdoor seating area. 
7.  Any outdoor seating or sidewalk café where liquor will be served shall comply with the provisions of chapter 5.32.063. 
B.  In addition to the requirements set forth in Section 5.60.040(A), the issuance and continued enjoyment of a sidewalk café license shall be conditioned on the following: 
1.  The use of public sidewalks or right-of-way for sidewalk cafés shall be permitted only on that portion of public property which is directly contiguous and immediately adjacent to the frontage or side yard of the private property in which the use is located. 
2.  Any person, partnership, firm, corporation or entity that applied for a sidewalk café license shall, prior to issuance of said license, present a certificate of general liability insurance, worker's compensation insurance and dram shop insurance (if applicable) that: 
a.  Names the village as an additional insured on its face; and 
b.  Is in an amount of at least one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per person; and 
c.  Is from a carrier acceptable to the village. 
3.  Any person, partnership, firm, corporation or entity that applied for a sidewalk café license shall provide, in a form acceptable to the village, an agreement to indemnify, defend, and hold harmless the village for any and all claims for liability or damages arising from the operation of the sidewalk café. 
4.  In no event shall the operation of the sidewalk café interfere with the passage of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, or reduce the open portion of the public sidewalk to less than four feet clear of all obstructions, measured from the edge of the sidewalk closest to the curb. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-15, § 1, 6-6-2011; Ord. No. 18-O-23, § 1, 6-18-2018) 
5.60.050 - Term of license; renewals. 
    Any license issued for operation of a sidewalk café or outdoor seating area shall expire on the next following April 1. Application to operate a sidewalk café or outdoor seating area for the next succeeding year shall be due prior to March 31 of each year, and no continuing operation of a sidewalk café or outdoor seating area shall be permitted unless and until a new license for the next year is issued. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-15, § 1, 6-6-2011) 
5.60.060 - Maintenance required. 
    The licensee shall be responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the public right-of-way used in the operation of outdoor seating and sidewalk cafés. The licensee shall not damage, alter, modify, or change any part of the public sidewalk or right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-15, § 1, 6-6-2011) 
5.60.070 - Cancellation or revocation of license. 
A.  Sidewalk café and outdoor seating licenses may be suspended, canceled and/or revoked by the village administrator at any time. 
B.  Sidewalk café and outdoor seating licenses do not constitute personal property, and the village shall retain at all times the right to terminate any license or may completely eliminate this class of license at any time. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-15, § 1, 6-6-2011) 
5.60.080 - Penalties. 
A.  Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount not exceeding seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day that such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
B.  Every act or omission constituting a violation of any provision of this chapter by any officer, director, manager, agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such employer or licensee and the employer or licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act or omission had been done or omitted by him or her personally. 
C.  Any violation committed pursuant to subsections A and B above, may result in the suspension, cancellation or revocation of sidewalk café and outdoor seating license. 
(Ord. No. 11-O-15, § 1, 6-6-2011) 
Chapter 5.60 - GARAGE SALES 
Sections: 

5.62.010 - Definition. 
    Garage Sale, shall be defined as the occasional sale, on a residential property, of miscellaneous secondhand merchandise to the public, where such sale is held or owned collectively by a group of persons, including the occupier of the premises where such sale is held. This term shall further include sales commonly known as estate sales, rummage sales, moving sales, community sales, barn sales and yard sales. No person, association, or corporation, shall engage in any garage sale in a Business District or Industrial District. 
(Ord. No. 17-O-41, § 1, 11-20-2017) 
Title 6 - ANIMALS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 6.04 - ADMINISTRATION AND DEFINITIONS 
Sections: 

6.04.010 - Animal warden. 
    There is created the position of animal warden for the village, who shall be appointed by the president with the consent of the board of trustees. In lieu of appointment to this position, the chief of police or his designee shall fulfill the duties of the animal warden or the corporate authorities may contract for the services of an animal warden and the duties imposed by this title shall be fulfilled by and executed by such person so contracted with. 
(Prior code § 13-1.1) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.04.020 - Duties of warden. 
    It shall be the duty of the animal warden to enforce all ordinances or provisions under this title, to exercise all powers enumerated herein and to issue citations for the enforcement of this title. 
(Prior code § 13-1.2) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.04.030 - Definitions. 
    Unless otherwise expressly stated, the following words or terms shall, for the purposes of this title, have the meanings indicated in this section: 
    "Animal" means any creature other than man. 
    "Bite" means any activity with the mouth of an animal which breaks through the skin, but does not necessarily have to draw blood and shall include abrasion of the skin or contact of saliva with any break or abrasion of skin, or mucous membrane. 
    "Cat" includes any feline. 
    "Cruelty to animals" means any one of the following activities: 
1.  To overwork, overdrive, beat, torture, torment, mutilate or inhumanely kill any animal; 
2.  To unnecessarily fail to provide any animal with proper food, drink, shelter and air; 
3.  To abandon or fail to reclaim any impounded animal; or 
4.  To inhumanely treat any animal in any manner. 
    "Diseased animal" means any animal infected with a contagious or infectious disease, including those diseases contagious or infectious only to animals. 
    "Dangerous animals" means those animals which has, without provocation, either bitten, injured, or attacked any person who was conducting himself in a peaceful and lawful manner or any animal which shall cause an annoyance or reasonable fear of bodily injury to any person by attacking or threatening to attack any such person or otherwise exhibiting fierce, dangerous or vicious propensities or any animal which has, without provocation, either bitten, injured or attacked any other animal or which are inherently incapable of being domesticated and are considered by the law to be inherently dangerous (ferae naturae). 
    "Dog" shall include any canine. 
    "Leash" means a strong cord, thong, chain, or similar device not more than ten (10) feet in length securely fastened to the collar or harness of a dog, cat or other animal, and held or physically controlled by the owner or such other person having control of the animal. 
    "Owner" means any person, firm, partnership, trustee, association, corporation having a right of property in an animal, or who keeps or harbors an animal, or who has it in his or her care, or acts as its custodian, or who knowingly permits an animal to remain on or about any premises occupied by him or her. 
    "Person" means any natural person, partnership, trust, corporation or association. Whenever used with respect to any penalty, the term "person", as applied to partnerships or associations, shall mean the partners or members thereof, and as applied to trusts or corporations, shall mean the trustees or officers thereof. 
    "Public or private nuisance" means any animal or animals which molests or attacks a person or passing vehicle, attacks other animals, is found to be a dangerous animal, is found to be running at large, damages private or public property or barks, whines, or howls in an excessive, continuous or untimely manner. 
(Prior code § 13-1.3) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
Chapter 6.08 - ANIMALS GENERALLY 
Sections: 

6.08.010 - Prohibited animals. 
A.  No person shall keep within the village any horse, pony, cattle, cow, buffalo, sheep, goat, chicken, goose, duck, turkey, pigeon, and other livestock or swine. 
B.  No person shall keep within the village any wild animal, including but not limited to any monkey, ape, raccoon, skunk, fox, poisonous or venomous snake or other reptile, snake over six feet in length, leopard, panther, tiger, lion, lynx or any other animal or bird which can normally be found in the wild state. 
(Ord. 02-O-29 § 1) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.08.015 - Keeping or confining animals. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to maintain or keep any pen, or other building or structure wherein domesticated animals are kept unless the same shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. 
B.  All pens, yards or runs or other structures wherein any animal is kept shall be of such construction so as to be easily cleaned and kept in good repair. 
C.  Fences which are intended as enclosure for any animal shall be securely constructed, shall be adequate for the purpose and kept in good repair and shall not be allowed to become unsightly. 
D.  It is unlawful for any person to permit the accumulation of animal waste on such person's property, so as to create a health hazard to the public or any odor disturbing to other persons. 
(Ord. 02-O-29 § 2) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.08.020 - Keeping of bees. 
    No person shall keep hives or swarms of bees in or upon his or her premises to the vexation, annoyance or damage to any other person. Whenever any complaint is made to village officials or to the police department, it shall be investigated and the owner or keeper of such swarms or hives of bees shall, if the occasion warrants, be given notice to remove the swarms or hives of bees, and shall so remove the same within five days from the receipt of the notice. 
(Prior code § 13-1.5) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.08.030 - Exhibition of dangerous animals. 
    It is unlawful for any person to exhibit or parade any dangerous animal within the village without first obtaining a permit from the chief of police and clerk. Such permit shall issue upon proper showing that the demonstration will be entirely safe to the public and upon payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each day or part of a day such exhibition of animals shall continue. 
(Prior code § 13-1.6) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.08.040 - Killing of dangerous animals. 
    The members of the police department may kill a dangerous animal or any other animal when it is necessary for the protection of the public, any person or property. 
(Prior code § 13-1.7) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.08.050 - Noisy animals. 
    It is unlawful to harbor or keep any animal which, by frequent or habitual barking, howling, yelping, bawling or other loud noise, shall cause annoyance of or continually disturbs the peace and quiet of any family, individual, neighborhood or place in the village any time of the day or night. 
(Prior code § 13-1.8) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.08.060 - Uncontrolled animals-Impoundment. 
    It is unlawful for the owner of any animal to allow such animal to be on the street as an uncontrolled animal. Any uncontrolled animal may be impounded by the chief of police, at the place and in the manner he shall provide for impoundment. 
A.  Impoundment Fee. No animal shall be removed from the pound until there shall be paid [a fee] in accordance with Section 6.12.170 of this title. 
B.  Any improper removal of any animal from the location for impounding uncontrolled animals shall be considered a violation of this section. 
C.  Disposal of Unclaimed Impounded Animals. Any impounded animal which remains unclaimed after three days from the time its owner is notified of its impoundment by the chief of police, or which remains unclaimed greater than twenty-four (24) hours after its impoundment and no owner is known or can be located, will be turned over to Lake County Animal Control. 
(Prior code § 13-1.9) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.08.070 - Cruelty to animals. 
    It is unlawful for any person, whether the owner or otherwise, to indulge in, or cause to be done any activities deemed to be cruelty to animals. 
(Prior code § 13-1.10) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.08.080 - Hunting of animals. 
    It is unlawful for any person to hunt or engage in killing any animal within the village limits, except as authorized under the provisions of this title. 
(Prior code § 13-1.11) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.08.090 - Indecent exhibition of animals. 
    It is unlawful for any person to exhibit any animal in an indecent manner, or to let any male animal to any female animal in a public place. 
(Prior code § 13-1.12) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.08.100 - Diseased animals. 
    It is unlawful for the owner of a diseased animal to allow such animal to be exposed in any manner in any public place; nor shall such diseased animal be shipped or removed from the premises of the owner thereof, except under the supervision of the chief of police. 
(Prior code § 13-1.13) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.08.110 - Dead animals. 
    It is unlawful for any person to allow any dead animal which he owned to remain within the village more than twenty-four (24) hours. No such animal shall be buried within the village limits. 
(Prior code § 13-1.14) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.08.120 - Slaughtering animals. 
    It is unlawful for any person to slaughter any animal or maintain any building for slaughtering any animal within the village limits. 
(Prior code § 13-1.15) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.08.130 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall be fined, pursuant to the provisions of this code, for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Prior code § 13-1.16) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
Chapter 6.12 - DOGS AND CATS 
Sections: 

6.12.010 - Limitation on number owned-License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or owner residing within the corporate limits of the village to own, keep or harbor at any time more than three dogs or three cats with a maximum of four in any combination thereof. 
    Owners/landlords of multi-unit housing, condominium associations, or other applicable authorities, may further limit the number of animals in said units. 
(Prior code § 13-2.1) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.12.020 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, adopted Jan. 4, 2010, repealed § 6.12.020, which pertained to license renewed and derived from § 13-2.2 of the prior code. 
6.12.030 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-0-05, § 1, adopted Jan. 4, 2010, repealed § 6.12.030, which pertained to license application and derived from § 13-2.3 of the prior code. 
6.12.040 - Rabies inoculation. 
    Every owner of a dog or cat shall cause such dog or cat to be inoculated against rabies by any licensed veterinarian or other county health department authorized authority, on a frequency specified by the county. 
1.  Certificate Evidence of Inoculation. Evidence of such inoculation shall consist of a certificate signed by the person administering the vaccine. 
2.  All Dogs or Cats Inoculated. It is unlawful for any person to bring any dog or cat into the village until such dog or cat has been inoculated as provided by the Illinois Revised Statutes. All such dogs or cats must also have a substantial collar, attached to which shall be a current metallic tag signifying a rabies inoculation within the last year. 
(Prior code § 13-2.4) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.12.050 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, adopted Jan. 4, 2010, repealed § 6.12.050, which pertained to registry for licensed dogs and cats and derived from § 13-2.5 of the prior code. 
6.12.060 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, adopted Jan. 4, 2010, repealed § 6.12.060, which pertained to no license fee and derived from § 13-2.6 of the prior code. 
6.12.070 - License tags. 
    Every dog or cat metallic tag indicating a rabies inoculation. 
A.  Metallic Rabies Tag. The metallic tag signifying a rabies inoculation will be issued by the proper authority specified by the county health department, or any licensed veterinarian as provided by 510 ILCS 5/8. 
B.  Attached to the Collar of Dog or Cat. Every dog or cat kept within the village shall be provided with a substantial collar by its owner who shall cause to be attached thereto in a secure manner, the metallic tag signifying a rabies inoculation. It is unlawful for any owner of any dog or cat to allow such dog or cat to be without a collar with a current rabies tag attached thereto. 
C.  Unauthorized Use of Original Tags. It is unlawful for any person to use or cause to be used the original rabies tag unless such tag is used on the same dog or cat for which it was issued. 
D.  Removal of Rabies Tag or Collar. It is unlawful for any person to remove the rabies tag or collar from any dog or cat without the owner's consent, except that the chief of police may authorize such removal during the course of normal impoundment. 
(Prior code § 13-2.7) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.12.080 - Control of dogs or cats. 
    Any dog or cat without a current rabies tag attached on its collar shall be considered an uncontrolled animal, and subject to imprisonment under Article 2 of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 13-2.8) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
Article 1. - General Provisions 

6.12.090 - Leashes. 
    It is unlawful for any owner of any dog or cat to allow such dog or cat to go upon any public street, alley or sidewalk or other public place unless such dog or cat is securely on a leash (also see Section 6.12.140). 
(Prior code § 13-2.9) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.12.100 - Dog or animal bite. 
    Whenever any dog or any animal bites a human being, the owner of such dog or animal shall immediately notify the chief of police who shall order the dog or animal to be held for a period of ten (10) days and such dog or animal shall be observed by a licensed veterinarian as may be required by the chief of police. It is unlawful for any person having knowledge of any person bitten by a dog or other animal to refuse to notify the chief of police or the county rabies inspector promptly. It is unlawful for the owner of such dog or animal to refuse or fail to comply with the written or printed recommendations made by the county rabies inspector or the chief of police, in any particular case. The written or printed recommendations shall be mailed by regular mail, postage prepaid, and addressed to the owner of the dog or other animal. The affidavit or testimony of the chief of police or the county rabies inspector who mailed such recommendations shall be prima facie evidence of the receipt of such recommendations by the owner of the dog or other animal. Any expense incurred in the handling of any dog or other animal under this shall be borne by the owner. 
(Prior code § 13-2.10) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.12.110 - Preventing spread of rabies. 
    Whenever a case of rabies has occurred within the village or surrounding locality, or when the village board of trustees is apprehensive of the spread of rabies, the chief of police may take the following steps to prevent its spread among dogs and other animals: 
A.  Require that all dogs or other animals be confined within an enclosure; 
B.  Require that owners of dogs or other animals take such prophylactic measures as he deems necessary to prevent the spread of rabies; 
C.  Determine the area and time during which the preventative measures of Subsections A. and B. of this section shall be effective. 
(Prior code § 13-2.11) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.12.120 - Dog or cat nuisances prohibited-Abatement. 
A.  Defecation. 
1.  It is unlawful for any owner of any dog or cat to permit such dog or cat to defecate on any street, sidewalk, alley or public place in the village, or on any private property, other than that of the dog or cat owner. Such defecation is declared to be a nuisance. 
2.  If any dog or cat shall defecate in violation of this subsection, the owner or person having control of the dog or cat shall immediately clean and remove the defecation. 
B.  Dangerous Dogs. It is declared to be a nuisance for the owner of any barking, howling, biting, vicious or dangerous dog to permit such dog to run at large, unattended as above provided, with the limits of the village, and any such person permitting such dog to run at large may be arrested, and such dog found running at large may be impounded as hereinafter provided. 
C.  Female in Heat. The owner of any female dog in heat shall keep the same confined or on a leash at all times and shall not permit such dog to be at large in the public ways, streets, parks or other public places in the village or on any premises other than those of the owner. 
(Prior code § 13-2.12) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
Article 2. - Impoundment 

6.12.130 - Definitions. 
    The terms used in this article have the following meaning: 
    "Dog" means any animal, male or female, of any kind or description, of the canine species, which is more than three months of age. 
    "Cat" means any animal, male or female, of any kind or description, of the carnivorous quadrupeds, of the genus felis species, which is more than three months of age. 
    "Owner" means any person who harbors or suffers or permits any dog or cat to be or remain at or about his or her house, store or other premises for a period of not less than thirty (30) days. 
(Prior code § 13-2.13-1) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.12.140 - Dogs or cats at large. 
    No owner of a dog or cat shall permit the dog or cat to run at large in any part of the village at any time. Any dog or cat off the premises of the owner and not under the control of the owner or a member of his or her immediate family of at least ten (10) years of age, by leash, shall be considered at large. A dog or cat within the care of its owner shall be deemed upon the owner's premises. Any dog or cat found at large in any street of the village, contrary to the provisions of this section shall be impounded as hereinafter provided. 
(Prior code § 13-2.13-2) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.12.150 - Impounding dogs or cats. 
    Any owner of a dog or cat who no longer desires to keep the dog or cat may voluntarily request the county animal control authority to pick up and take possession of the dog or cat and grant the right to dispose of the dog or cat as provided for under the terms of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 13-2.13-3) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.12.160 - Redemption of impounded dogs or cats. 
A.  Unclaimed Dogs or Cats. Any dog or cat for which the owner is not known which is impounded shall be securely chained or confined, separate from all other impounded dogs or cats, for a period of no greater than twenty-four (24) hours. If a dog so impounded remains unclaimed, it shall be forwarded to Lake County Animal Control authorities by the chief of police or his/her designee. 
B.  Dogs or Cats. Any dog or cat for which the owner is known which is impounded shall be securely chained or confined, separate from all other impounded dogs or cats. The animal warden shall, within twenty-four (24) hours of such impounding, attempt by telephone or registered mail to notify the owner of record of such dog or cat. If a dog or cat for which the owner is known remains unclaimed after impounding for no greater than twenty-four (24) hours, All unredeemed and unwanted dogs or cats regardless of licensing status, shall be disposed of at the discretion of the chief of police within twenty-four (24) hours of impounding. 
C.  Dogs or Cats without Identification. The village shall not be required to notify an owner of the impounding of a dog or cat if such animal lacks the proper means of identification when impounded. A reasonable effort to identify the owner shall be made from whatever source is available. Redemption and disposal of such dog shall be as set forth in Subsection B. of this section. 
(Prior code § 13-2.13-4) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.12.170 - Impounding fee. 
    The impounding fee must be as stated below, plus all animal hospital boarding fees incurred by the village for each animal so impounded: 
First offense $25.00, 
plus boarding fee Second offense $30.00, 
plus boarding fee Third offense $35.00, 
plus boarding fee Each offense 
thereafter $40.00, 
plus boarding fee  
Boarding fee is thirty dollars ($30.00) per day. 
(Prior code § 13-2.14) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
6.12.180 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined pursuant to this code for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Prior code § 13-2.15) 
(Ord. No. 10-O-05, § 1, 1-4-2010) 
Title 8 - HEALTH AND SAFETY 
Chapter 8.04 - HEALTH ADMINISTRATION 

8.04.010 - Board of health. 
A.  Creation. There is created and established a board of health for the village. The board shall consist of the president of the village, who shall be ex officio president of the board of health, and the trustees. 
B.  Meetings. The board of health shall meet at such times and places as it may determine. 
C.  Attendance of Health Officer. The board of health may require the health officer to attend any of its meetings, and to give to the board such information, recommendations or advice as it may desire. 
D.  Rules and Regulations. The board of health shall have the power to make reasonable rules and regulations for the protection and betterment of the health of the residents of the village, for the abatement of nuisances to health, and for the prevention and suppression of disease. Such rules and regulations shall take effect and be in force ten (10) days after publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the village, except in cases of emergency as hereinafter provided. In case of contagious or epidemic disease, or of danger from anticipated or impending contagious or epidemic disease, or in case the sanitary condition of the village shall be so dangerous as to warrant it, it shall be the duty of the board of health to make such rules and regulations, and to take such measures, and to do and order to be done and cause to be done such acts for the preservation of the public health (though not herein or elsewhere or otherwise specifically authorized) as it may in good faith believe and declare for public safety and health demand. All such rules and regulations so declared by the board of health to be emergency rules and regulations, shall take effect immediately, or as soon as may be, after the promulgation of the same by the board of health. The emergency rules and regulations shall also be published in such manner as the board of health shall determine, with notice that they are in force in the village. 
(Prior code § 11.01) 
8.04.020 - Health officer. 
A.  Duties and Powers. In addition to other duties prescribed by this code, it shall be the duty of the health officer to execute and enforce all statutes of the state of Illinois, provisions of this code, and rules and regulations of the board of health relating to health, and to take such other action as is necessary for the promotion and improvement of the public health, not inconsistent with the foregoing statutes, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
B.  Deputy Building Inspector. The health officer is made a deputy building inspector. It shall be made his or her duty to aid the building inspector in administering and enforcing the provisions of building ordinances pertaining to health and sanitation. 
C.  Hearings on Violations. When it appears that any state statute or provision of this code relating to health or any rule or regulation of the board of health has been violated, the health officer shall cause notice of such fact to be given to the person concerned, who shall be given an opportunity to be heard before the board of health concerning such alleged violation. The notice shall specify the date, hour and place of hearing and the hearing shall be private. If, after such hearing, the board of health shall believe the ordinance or regulation has been violated, it shall cause the violator to be prosecuted. 
(Prior code § 11.02) 
8.04.030 - Enforcement of health regulations. 
    It is the duty of every member of the police department to aid in the enforcement of any order issued by the authority of the board of health. 
(Prior code § 11.03) 
8.04.040 - Registrar of vital statistics. 
A.  The village clerk shall be registrar of vital statistics for the village. 
B.  A report of all births, still births, and deaths shall be made to the local registrar of vital statistics, which report shall contain all information required by the Vital Records Act, 410 ILCS 535/1-535/29, as amended from time to time. 
C.  The local registrar shall keep a record showing all births, still births, and deaths occurring within the village, which record shall include all the information required to be kept by the Vital Records Act. 
(Editorially amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 11.04) 
Chapter 8.08 - DUTCH ELM DISEASE 

8.08.010 - Inspection. 
    The officers, agents and employees of the village may enter upon private property whereon there is located any elm tree having the appearance of or suspected of being diseased with the Dutch Elm disease, for the purpose of inspecting the suspected tree and removing therefrom samples or portions thereof to be tested to establish whether the tree is in fact diseased. 
(Prior code § 12.05(a)) 
8.08.020 - Nuisance. 
    If it is determined by the village that the tree from which samples have been taken is in fact diseased or infected with the Dutch Elm disease, the tree shall be deemed a nuisance. 
(Prior code § 12.05(b)) 
8.08.030 - Destruction of affected trees. 
    The owner, occupant or agent of the parcel of land on which the diseased elm tree exists, shall remove and destroy the elm tree within ten (10) days after notification to such owner, occupant or agent, by the village that the elm tree situated on the parcel of land is in fact diseased and infected. 
(Prior code § 12.05(c)) 
8.08.040 - Abatement by village. 
    In case the owner, occupant or agent of the parcel of land on which a diseased elm tree is located cannot be found, or if found and notified as aforesaid, neglects or refuses to abate the nuisance, the village may abate the same by the removal and destruction of the diseased elm tree, and the owner, occupant and agent or any of them, shall be charge with those expenses which may be incurred by the village in the removal of the diseased elm tree, which expense shall be collected by the village by suit, or otherwise. In addition the owner, occupant or agent shall be subject to the fine or penalty provided in this chapter. 
(Prior code § 12.05(d)) 
8.08.050 - Lien for removal costs. 
    The cost of removal and destruction of a diseased elm tree is a lien upon the real estate affected, superior to all other liens and encumbrances, except tax liens; provided, that notice has been given as hereinafter described; and further provided, that within sixty (60) days after such cost and expense is incurred the village, or person performing the service by authority of the village, in his or her own name, files notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds of Lake County. The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting out: (1) a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; (2) the amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service; and (3) the date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the village. Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner of or persons interested in such property, after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the village, or person in whose name the lien has been filed, and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. The cost of such tree removal shall not be a lien upon the real estate affected unless a notice shall be personally served or sent by registered mail to the person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes for the last preceding year on the property, such notice to be delivered or sent not less than thirty (30) days prior to the removal of the tree or trees located thereon. The notice shall contain the substance of this chapter and identify the property, by common description, and the tree or trees affected. 
(Prior code § 12.05(e)) 
8.08.060 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or who shall neglect or refuse to remove and destroy a diseased elm tree growing on any parcel of land of which such person is owner, agent, occupant, or person in possession, when ordered so to do, or who shall interfere with the removal and destruction of such diseased elm tree, shall be subject to the penalty provided for violation of this code. 
(Prior code § 12.05(f)) 
Chapter 8.12 - EMERGENCY 911 TELEPHONE SYSTEM 

8.12.010 - Intergovernmental cooperation agreement. 
    The village of Round Lake shall by means of an intergovernmental cooperation agreement participate with the villages of Hainesville, Round Lake, Round Lake Beach, Round Lake Heights, and Round Lake Park, and such other municipalities as shall from time to time elect to participate in a joint emergency telephone system agency (designated as "Cencom E-9-l-1 Emergency Telephone System") pursuant to Section 15.4 of the Emergency Telephone System Act (50 ILCS Act 750). 
(Editorially amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 3.20(a)) 
8.12.020 - Definitions. 
    For purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply:
