Chapter 15.32 - APPEARANCE CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-O-12, § 2, adopted June 4, 2012, repealed Ch. 15.32 and enacted a new chapter as set out herein. The former Ch. 15.32, §§ 15.32.010-15.32.050, pertained to signs and derived from §§ 28.03-28.06 and § 28.08 of the prior code. 

15.32.010 - Appearance code adopted. 
    That certain document captioned "Village of Round Lake Appearance Code" dated June 4, 2012 as set forth in Ordinance 12-O-13, is adopted by reference and shall be part of the Round Lake Village Code as if fully set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 12-O-12, § 2, 6-4-2012; Ord. No. 12-O-13, § 1, 6-4-2012) 
15.32.020 - Enforcement. 
    The procedures and penalties in effect for violations of the property maintenance code of Chapter 15.28 of the Village Code shall govern violations of the appearance code. 
(Ord. No. 12-O-12, § 2, 6-4-2012) 
15.32.030 - Hearings for certificates of appropriateness, appeals. 
A.  Plan Commission/Zoning Board of Appeals. The plan commission/zoning board of appeals shall hear all applications under this chapter. 
B.  Downtown Business District Advisory Commission. For those developments or projects which otherwise require review by the downtown business district advisory commission, all applications for a certificate of appropriateness, variation from the appearance code, or appeals under this chapter shall be heard by the business district advisory commission. 
C.  References to the "commission" below refer to the plan commission/zoning board of appeals. 
(Ord. No. 12-O-12, § 2, 6-4-2012; Ord. No. 13-O-12, § 5, 9-3-2013; Ord. No. 13-O-19, § 4, 10-7-2013) 
15.32.050 - Certificate of appropriateness for landscaping and building facades. 
A.  Building Facades and Exterior Areas. No multi-family building containing three or more units, mix use building, commercial or industrial building shall be constructed or altered in any zoning district unless and until a certificate of appropriateness is granted as set forth in the appearance code. 
B.  Landscaping of Commercial and Industrial Uses. No permit for landscape construction or installation for commercial or industrial properties shall be issued by the economic and community development director or his designee until a certificate of appropriateness is granted as set forth in the appearance code. 
C.  Waiver. The economic and community development director or his designee is authorized to waive the certificate of appropriateness required under this section if he or she determines that no external architectural feature is involved or the work is minor in nature for which the permit is sought. 
D.  No Delay in Collateral Review of Plans. The fact that an application for a certificate of appropriateness has been filed shall not be cause for the delay of the review of plans relating to the building and zoning aspects of the project, while the application is pending. 
(Ord. No. 12-O-12, § 2, 6-4-2012; Ord. No. 18-O-21, § 6, 5-21-2018) 
15.32.060 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-O-38, § 12, adopted Dec. 17, 2018, repealed § 15.32.060, which pertained to sign permits and derived from Ord. No. 12-O-12, § 2, 6-4-2012; Ord. No. 13-O-12, § 5, 9-3-2013; Ord. No. 18-O-21, § 6, 5-21-2018. 
15.32.065 - Application for sign permit. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-O-38, § 12, adopted Dec. 17, 2018, repealed § 15.32.065, which pertained to application for sign permit and derived from Ord. No. 12-O-12, § 2, 6-4-2012; Ord. No. 18-O-21, § 6, 5-21-2018. 
15.32.070 - Application for certificate of appropriateness. 
A.  Form. An application for a certificate of appropriateness shall be made by the applicant upon such forms as may be provided by the community development department. 
B.  Contents of Application. The application shall contain the following information: 
1.  Name, address and telephone number of applicant. 
2.  Written consent of the legal owner of the building or structure. 
3.  Location of the improvement, building, or structure to be constructed or altered. 
4.  Detailed site plan, showing north reference; square foot area calculations for building, pavement and landscaping; dimensioned property lines; easements and building setbacks; adjacent streets, alleys and sidewalks; parking spaces including handicapped spaces; trash/refuse location and enclosures; proposed equipment (generators, compactors, transformers, HVAC, etc.); and existing and proposed contours at two feet zero inches maximum intervals (if applicable). 
5.  Landscape Plan. The landscape plan shall be rendered in color and include a depiction of: existing vegetation noting species, size and drip lines of trees two and one-half inches and larger, with a distinction shown between vegetation to be retained or removed; new plant material noting quantities, species (botanical and common names), and size (in caliper for trees or height of multi-stemmed shrubs at time of installation), and graphically distinguishing between new and existing plant material and between species of new plant material; site furnishings and specialties; paving materials; height and locations of flag poles, signage, light standards and fences; screening, noting materials used as screen, height of screen material, device or area which requires screening and height of device to be screened (exterior areas which require screening include parking, refuse storage and mechanical equipment); and storm water retention/detention areas. 
6.  Lighting Plan. A separate overlay to the above referenced site plan with site and building lighting highlighted. Documentation must include photometric documentation or separate print-out showing compliance with the zoning ordinance, reference code keyed to light fixture catalog cuts and lamp types. 
7.  Building Plan. Documentation shall include a grade level plan (minimum scale one-eighth inch = one foot zero inches) which indicates openings and articulation of the exterior wall and the relationship of this level to the project site; floor plans of all levels on separate drawings; roof plan with equipment, skylights and other appropriate features; and graphically distinguish between new and existing construction. 
8.  Building Elevations. A drawing (minimum scale one-eighth inch = one foot zero inches) which provides exterior views of all new and existing building facades and indicates the relationships of all visible building features and color rendering of significant views. 
9.  Site Section. A section through the site at appropriate locations indicating buildings, trees, light standards, grade variations, fences and other critical structures. Reference plane of section cuts to site plan. 
10.  Scale Model or Building Perspective. A scale model or color rendering of significant views of the building and its surrounding area; and 
11.  Material Samples. A display board which illustrates actual site and building materials. Samples shall provide an accurate representation of color, texture, finish and range variations. 
12.  Photographs. Current color photographs of the site showing all building elevations, surrounding properties and landscape views. The format shall be a minimum four inches × six inches size color print. Panoramic photographs are preferred. 
C.  As appropriate for each project, the economic and community development director may waive certain application requirements or require additional materials in order to evaluate the application. 
(Ord. No. 12-O-12, § 2, 6-4-2012; Ord. No. 18-O-21, § 6, 5-21-2018) 
15.32.080 - Certificate of appropriateness procedure. 
A.  Preliminary Consideration. Prior to submitting a formal, completed application for a certificate of appropriateness, an applicant may request a preliminary design critique from the plan commission. Applicants must request a preliminary design critique in writing and submit sufficient materials to adequately portray the design concept and its relationship to adjacent properties. Submissions may be significantly abbreviated and need not include all of the items required for formal consideration of a certificate of appropriateness. A certificate of appropriateness will not be issued based upon a preliminary submission. 
B.  Action by Commission. The commission shall formally consider the application at a regular or special meeting held in compliance with the Open Meetings Act. The applicant shall have the opportunity to present evidence in support of the application. The commission shall allow the public to comment on any application at such meeting. The commission shall make its decision at the meeting in which the case is heard, unless it determines that it needs additional evidence and continues the application to another date, at which time a decision shall be rendered. The action of the commission shall be final. 
C.  Standards for Approval. The commission shall issue a certificate of appropriateness, unless the commission finds that the plan does not conform to the appearance code. 
D.  Approval by Commission. The commission shall approve a certificate of appropriateness upon the concurring vote of the majority of the commission members present. A vote of "abstain" or "present" shall be counted with the majority. 
(Ord. No. 12-O-12, § 2, 6-4-2012; Ord. No. 13-O-12, § 5, 9-3-2013) 
15.32.090 - Variations from appearance code. 
A.  Process. Property owners may seek relief from the strict application of the appearance code by applying for a variation. 
B.  Notice. Not less than fifteen (15) nor more than thirty (30) days prior to the hearing on an application for variation, the applicant shall send written notice via first class mail, postage prepaid, to all owners of property located within two hundred fifty (250) feet in any direction from any boundary of the subject property. The applicant shall present an affidavit of mailing at the hearing on the variation. 
C.  Public Hearing. The plan commission shall hold a public hearing on the application for variation as soon as practicable after the application is received. 
D.  Standards for Variations. If the plan commission finds that the application for a variation meets the following standards, it shall grant the variation: 
1.  The granting of the variations will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property or improvements in the neighborhood in which the property is located. 
2.  The variation requested presents unique circumstances which are not addressed in the appearance code and which are not generally applicable to all properties in the village. 
3.  The variation requested will allow for the improvement of the subject property in a manner which is not possible without the variation. 
E.  Approval by Commission. An application for variation may be approved upon the concurring vote of the majority of the commission members present. A vote of "abstain" or "present" shall be counted with the majority. The commission's decision shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 12-O-12, § 2, 6-4-2012; Ord. No. 13-O-12, § 5, 9-3-2013) 
15.32.100 - Appeal from decisions of commission. 
    All final decisions of the plan commission may be appealed to the president and board of trustees. Appeals must be made in writing directed to the president and board of trustees and received by the village clerk within twenty-one (21) days of the final decision being appealed. In ruling on an appeal, the president and board of trustees may affirm, reverse, or refer the matter back to the commission for further hearing. The affirmative vote of a majority of the corporate authorities shall be required to reverse the determination of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 12-O-12, § 2, 6-4-2012; Ord. No. 13-O-12, § 5, 9-3-2013) 
15.32.110 - Approved plans. 
    Upon the granting of a certificate of appropriateness, the exterior drawings, sketches, landscape and site plans, renderings and materials upon which the certificate was granted shall be deemed the "approved plans." The economic and community development director shall inspect the project from time to time to determine that there are no substantial deviations from the approved plans. The economic and community development director may, after the issuance of a certificate of appropriateness, approve minor changes in a project. 
(Ord. No. 12-O-12, § 2, 6-4-2012; Ord. No. 18-O-21, § 6, 5-21-2018) 
15.32.120 - Responsibilities. 
    In the event of any absence of the economic and community development director, the village administrator shall perform the responsibilities of the economic and community development director as specified in this code. 
(Ord. No. 12-O-12, § 2, 6-4-2012; Ord. No. 18-O-21, § 7, 5-21-2018) 
Chapter 15.36 - MOBILEHOME PARKS 
Sections: 

15.36.010 - Definitions. 
    Terms used in this chapter have the following meanings: 
    "Mobilehome" means any vehicle or similar portable structure used or so constructed as to permit its being used as a conveyance upon the public streets, and designed to permit the occupancy thereof as a dwelling for one or more persons. 
    "Mobilehome park" means an area of land on which two or more occupied mobilehomes are harbored, either free of charge or for revenue, together with any building structure or enclosure used as part of the equipment of such park. 
(Prior code § 14.01) 
15.36.020 - License required. 
    It is unlawful to establish, maintain or operate any mobilehome park in the village without first having obtained a license therefor. Application for such license shall be made in writing to the village clerk in compliance with the ordinances relating to license applications, and shall contain the name of the applicant, the location of the proposed park, and the number of mobilehomes to be accommodated. 
(Prior code § 14.02) 
15.36.030 - Plan. 
    Each such application shall be accompanied by a plat or sketch showing the size and location of all buildings and structures. 
(Prior code § 14.03) 
15.36.040 - Fee. 
    The annual fee for such license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) plus three dollars ($3.00) for each mobilehome over thirty-five (35). If the accommodations are increased for any park during the license year, this shall be reported to the village clerk and the additional fee, if any, necessitated by such increase, shall be paid before the additional spaces are put to use. When a license is applied for, or accommodations are increased during the license year, the fee shall be prorated on the basis of the number of months remaining in the license year. 
(Editorially amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 14.04) 
15.36.050 - Character of operator. 
    No such license shall be issued to any but a person of good character, nor to any corporation if any officer thereof is not a person of good character. It is unlawful to hire or keep as manager, superintendent or person in charge of a mobilehome park, any person who is not a person of good character, or any person who has been convicted of a felony. 
(Prior code § 14.05) 
15.36.060 - Supervision. 
    Each mobilehome park, while operated, shall be in the charge of a responsible attendant or caretaker at all times, who shall be responsible with the licensee for compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 14.06) 
15.36.070 - Spaces. 
    Each mobilehome shall be allotted a site of not less than three thousand two hundred (3,200) square feet, exclusive of common driveways. No mobilehome shall be parked closer than seven and one-half feet to the side lot lines of a mobilehome park, if the abutting property is improved property, or closer than fifteen (15) feet to a public street, alley or building. Each individual mobilehome site shall abut or face on a driveway or clear unoccupied space of not less than twenty-four (24) feet in width, which driveway or space shall have unobstructed access to a public highway or alley; a single detached storage shed as required in Section 15.36.090 shall be permitted within the clear unoccupied space required in this section, provided that such shed complies with all applicable building and safety codes. There shall be an open space of not less than fifteen (15) feet between the sides of every mobilehome and at least ten (10) feet between the ends of every mobilehome. No mobilehome park shall be operated on less than ten (10) acres. Mobilehomes shall be not less than twelve (12) feet in width and not less than fifty (50) feet in length. 
(Prior code § 14.07) 
(Ord. No. 11-O-19, § 1, 8-1-2011) 
15.36.080 - Improvements-Parking. 
    The owner or developer of a mobilehome park shall provide paved streets, curbs and gutters, and shall also provide adequate storm water drainage, the design of which shall be approved by the village engineer. Streets shall be maintained and kept in good repair by the owner of the mobilehome park. A driveway shall be provided on each site whereon automobiles owned or operated by the residents of such site shall be parked. Additional parking for visitors shall be centrally provided. All mobilehomes shall be skirted with aluminum within thirty (30) days after the mobilehome is moved into the park. Each mobilehome site shall be sodded immediately upon occupancy of such site. 
(Prior code § 14.08) 
15.36.090 - Garbage storage. 
    A storage shed for garbage cans shall be constructed on each mobilehome site, and garbage cans shall be kept therein at all times out of the public view. Garbage pick-up and removal shall be provided twice weekly. 
(Prior code § 14.09) 
(Ord. No. 11-O-19, § 1, 8-1-2011) 
15.36.100 - Utilities-Concrete pads. 
    A central television antenna shall be provided by the owner of the mobilehome park, and connecting wires from the central tower to the individual home site, as well as electrical and telephone wires, shall be installed underground. Electric street lights of at least four hundred (400) wattage, mercury vapor or its equivalent, shall be installed at intervals of not more than seven hundred (700) feet; provided, that coach lights are installed at each mailbox; if coach lights are not installed at each mailbox, electric light standards shall be placed at not less than three hundred (300) foot intervals. Concrete pads or runners must be reinforced with steel rod or mesh. The location of fire hydrants shall be approved by the fire department serving the mobilehome park. 
(Prior code § 14.10) 
15.36.110 - Water supply. 
    An adequate supply of pure water for drinking and domestic purposes from the village's water supply system shall be supplied to meet the requirements of a mobilehome park. 
(Prior code § 14.11) 
15.36.120 - Sanitary sewers. 
    Each mobilehome park shall be connected to the sanitary sewer system of the village and comply with the ordinances of the Round Lake sanitary district. 
(Prior code § 14.12) 
15.36.130 - State regulations. 
    In addition to the provisions of this chapter, the owner and operator of a mobilehome park shall comply with all of the provisions of the act known as the Mobile Home Park Act, 210 ILCS 115. 
(Editorially amended during 2001 codification; prior code § 14.13) 
15.36.140 - Permanent use allowed in park only. 
    It is unlawful for any person to maintain any mobilehome for human habitation upon any plot of ground in the village, except in a licensed mobilehome park. 
(Prior code § 14.14) 
Chapter 15.40 - RECREATIONAL VEHICLE PARKS 
Sections: 

15.40.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to enforce minimum standards for recreational vehicle parks, establish requirements for the design, construction, alteration, extension and maintenance of recreational vehicle parks and related utilities and facilities; authorize the issuance of permits for construction, alteration and extension of recreational vehicle parks; authorize the licensing of operators of recreational vehicle parks; authorize the inspection of recreational vehicle parks; and fix penalties for violations. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 (part)) 
15.40.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Applicant" means any person making application for a license or permit. 
    "BOCA Building Code" means the latest edition of the BOCA Basic Building Code as copyrighted by the Building Officials and Code Administrators International, effective on the date of passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter or as subsequently amended by the village. 
    "Department" means the building and zoning department of the village. 
    "Driveway" means a minor private way used by vehicles and pedestrians on a lot or used for common access to a small group of lots or facilities. 
    "Food service" means the distribution or sale of food prepared for exclusive consumption within the park by (private park) members or employees. 
    "Food service facility" means a fixed location for the distribution of food services. 
    "Group camping" means the assembly of not more than forty (40) recreational vehicles and/or tents when registered as a group in advance with the park management. Normally, these groups are youth, scouting and clubs in an approved designated area for the purpose of recreational camping. However, there may be more than one recreational vehicle or tent located on any one lot, provided they maintain at least ten (10) feet of separation between every tent and/or recreational vehicle. 
    "Gross acreage" means, for the purposes of this chapter, the entire acreage of the proposed recreational campsite. 
    "Health authority" means the health department of Lake County. 
    "IDOT" means the Illinois Department of Transportation. 
    "License" means a written license issued by the village allowing a person to operate and maintain a recreational vehicle park under the provisions of this chapter and regulations issued hereunder. 
    "Lot" means a parcel of land for the placement of a single recreational vehicle or tent and the exclusive use of its occupants. 
    "Sanitary station" means a facility used for removing and disposing of wastes from (recreational vehicle) holding tanks. 
    "Service building" means structures, housing facilities accessory to the recreational park. 
    "Sewer connection" means the connection consisting of all pipes, fittings and appurtenances from the drain outlet of a recreational vehicle, if any, to the inlet of the corresponding sewer riser pipe of the sewerage system serving the recreational park. 
    "Sewer riser pipe" means that portion of the sewer lateral which extends vertically to the ground elevation and terminates at a lot. 
    "Stand" means that part of an individual lot which has been reserved for the placement of one recreational vehicle or tent. For purposes of this chapter, the commonly used term "pad" shall be considered synonymous with "stand." 
    Street, Park. "Park street" means a private way which affords principal means of access into or from the recreational park or to individual lots or auxiliary buildings within the recreational vehicle park. 
    Street, Entrance. "Entrance street" means any park street which connects with an improved public street and is utilized for vehicular access to and from the recreational vehicle park. Any such park street shall be considered an entrance street for a distance of 100 feet from its intersection with an improved public street. 
    Street, Collector. "Collector street" means any park street which extends from a park entrance street and intersects with three or more other streets or any street that intersects with six or more other streets or any street which extends for more than one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet without intersection with another street. 
    Street, Minor. "Minor street" means any park street which is neither an entrance nor a collector street. 
    Street, Cul-de-sac. "Cul-de-sac street" means a minor street having only one entrance and terminating in a loop or other suitable terminus. 
    "Tent" means a collapsible shelter of canvas or other material stretched and sustained by poles fixed in the ground and used for a temporary outdoor camping shelter. 
    "Tent site" means an area specifically designated for the use of tents as described above. 
    "Water connection" means the connection consisting of all pipes, fittings and appurtenances from the water riser pipe to the water inlet pipe of the distribution system within a recreational vehicle. 
    "Water riser pipe" means that portion of the water supply system serving the recreational vehicle park which extends vertically to the ground elevation and terminates at a designated point of each lot. 
    "ZBA" means the village zoning board of appeals. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 § 1.1) 
15.40.030 - Permits. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to construct, alter or extend any recreational vehicle park within the incorporated area of the village in the county of Lake, in the state of Illinois, unless he or she holds a valid permit issued by the village in the name of such person for the specific construction, alteration or extension proposed. A permit issued for a recreational vehicle park shall be clearly identified and distinguished from a permit for a mobilehome park. 
B.  All applications for permits shall contain the following: 
1.  Name and address of applicant; 
2.  Interest of the applicant in the proposed recreational vehicle park; 
3.  Name and address of all persons holding an interest or having an interest in the proposed recreational vehicle park; 
4.  Location and legal description of the recreational vehicle park; 
5.  Complete engineering plans and specifications of the proposed recreational vehicle park showing but not limited to the following: 
a.  The area and dimensions of the tract of land, 
b.  The number, location and size of all improved lots and group camping areas intended for use by recreational vehicles or tents, 
c.  The number, location and size of all unimproved lots intended for use by recreational vehicles or tents, 
d.  The location and width of roadways and walkways, 
e.  The location of water and sewer lines, 
f.  Plans and specifications of the water supply, refuse and sewage disposal facilities, and pet exercise and sanitation areas, 
g.  Plans and specifications of all buildings constructed within the recreational vehicle park, 
h.  The location and details of lighting and electrical system, 
i.  Location of fire hydrants, if provided, 
j.  Location of all paved areas, 
k.  Quantity and point or area of departure of storm water runoff prior to and subsequent to construction of a proposed recreational vehicle park. Engineering plans and calculations for these measurements shall be approved by the village consulting engineer, 
l.  Erosion control and landscaping plan; 
6.  The calendar months of the year during which the applicant will operate the proposed recreational vehicle park; 
7.  Description of operation: public, private, membership, fee simple, life, annual, etc. 
C.  All applications shall be accompanied by the deposit of a nonrefundable fee as established by the village. 
D.  When, upon review of the application, the department has determined that the proposed plan meets the requirements of this chapter, and has been certified by the state of Illinois, a permit shall be issued. 
E.  Any person whose application for a permit under this chapter has been denied may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the Round Lake zoning board of appeals under the procedure provided by Section 15.40.060. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 §§ 2.1-2.5) 
15.40.040 - Licenses. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to operate any recreational vehicle park within the incorporated area of the village unless he or she holds a valid license issued annually by the village in the name of such person for the specific recreational vehicle park. All applications for licenses shall be made to the department which shall issue a license upon compliance by the applicant with provisions of this chapter. A license issued for a recreational vehicle park shall be clearly identified and distinguished from a license from a mobilehome park. 
B.  Every person holding a license shall give notice in writing to the village within twenty-four (24) hours after having sold, transferred, given away or otherwise disposed of interest in or control of any recreational vehicle park. Such notice shall include the name and address of the person succeeding to the ownership or control of such recreational vehicle park. Upon application in writing for transfer of the license shall be transferred if the recreational vehicle park is in compliance with all applicable provisions of this chapter. 
C.  1.  Applications for licenses shall be in writing and signed by the applicant. The application shall contain the following: 
a.  The name, address and legal interest of the applicant in the site; 
b.  The location and legal description of the recreational vehicle park; 
c.  A site plan of the recreational vehicle park showing all improved lots, unimproved lots, group camping areas, structures, walkways, if any, roads, service facilities and pet exercise and sanitation stations. 
2.  Applications for renewals of licenses shall be made in writing by the holders of the licenses; shall be accompanied by the deposit of a nonrefundable fee as established by the board of trustees; and shall contain any change in the information submitted since the original license was issued or the latest renewal granted. 
D.  Any person whose application for a license under this chapter has been denied may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the Round Lake zoning board of appeals under the procedure provided by Section 15.40.060. 
E.  Whenever, upon inspection of any recreational vehicle park, the village finds that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of any provision of this chapter, the village shall give notice in writing in accordance with Section 15.40.060(A) to the person to whom the license was issued that unless such conditions or practices are corrected within a reasonable period of time specified in the notice by the village, the license shall be suspended. At the end of such period, the village shall reinspect such recreational vehicle park and, if such conditions or practices have not been corrected, the village shall revoke the license and give notice in writing of such revocation to the person to whom the license was issued. Upon receipt of such notice of revocation, such person shall cease operation of such recreational vehicle park except as provided in Section 15.40.060(B). 
F.  An annual fee for licensing the operation of a public or private recreational vehicle park shall be based on the number of campsite lots, for which a rental fee will be charged by the owner, as follows: 
    For the first two hundred (200) lots improved or unimproved ten dollars ($10.00) per lot; any lots thereafter only upon issuance of a special permit by the village board. 
G.  An annual business license fee of forty dollars ($40.00) will be required for the operation of a business located on the premises such as supply store, game room, souvenir shop, food service facility and/or any commercial enterprise for which a service and/or a product is sold for a fee. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 §§ 3.1-3.7) 
15.40.050 - Inspection of recreational vehicle park. 
A.  The village and the Lake County health authority are authorized and directed to make such inspections as are necessary to determine satisfactory compliance with this chapter, but in no case shall such inspection take place less than twice per year. 
B.  The village and the Lake County health authority shall have the power to enter at reasonable times upon any private or public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions relating to the enforcement of this chapter. 
C.  The village and the Lake County health authority shall have the power to inspect the register containing a record of all occupants of the recreational vehicle park. 
D.  It shall be the duty of the park management to give the village free access to all lots and other areas at reasonable times for the purpose of inspection including inspection by police or fire personnel. 
E.  It shall be the duty of every occupant of a recreational vehicle park to give the owner thereof or his or her agent or employee access to any part of such recreational vehicle park at reasonable times for the purpose of making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 §§ 4.1-4.5) 
15.40.060 - Notices, hearings and orders. 
A.  Whenever the village determines that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter, the village shall give notice of such alleged violation to the person to whom the permit or license was issued, as hereinafter provided. 
    Such notice shall: 
1.  Be in writing; 
2.  Include a statement of the reasons for its issuance; 
3.  Allow a reasonable time for the performance of any act it requires; 
4.  Be deemed to have been properly served upon such owner or agent when he or she has been served with such notice by any method authorized or required by state law; and 
5.  Contain an outline of remedial action which, if taken, will effect compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  Any person affected by any notice of suspension or revocation which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provision of this chapter shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the zoning board of appeals; provided, that such person shall file in the office of the zoning board of appeals a written petition requesting such hearing and setting forth the grounds therefore, together with a filing fee as prescribed by the village board in its fee schedule, within fifteen (15) days after the day the notice was served. The filing of the request for a hearing shall operate as a stay of the notice and of the suspension except in the case of an order issued under subsection E of this section. Upon receipt of such petition, the zoning board of appeals shall set a time and place for such hearing and shall give the petitioner written notice thereof. At such hearing the petitioner shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show why such notice should be modified or withdrawn. The hearing shall be commenced not later than fifteen (15) days after the day on which the petition was filed; provided, that upon application of the petitioner, the zoning board of appeals may postpone the date of hearing for a reasonable time beyond such fifteen (15) day period when in its judgment the petitioner has submitted good and sufficient reasons for such postponement. 
C.  After such hearing, the ZBA shall make findings as to compliance with the provisions of this chapter and shall issue an order in writing sustaining, modifying or withdrawing the notice which shall be served as provided in subsection (A)(4) of this section. Upon failure to comply with any order sustaining or modifying a notice, the license of the recreational vehicle park affected by the order shall be revoked. 
D.  The proceedings of such a hearing, including the findings and decision of the ZBA, together with a copy of every notice and order related thereto shall be entered as a matter of public record in the office of the ZBA, but the transcript of the proceedings need not be transcribed unless judicial review of the decision is sought as provided by this section. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the ZBA may seek relief therefrom in accordance with the Administrative Review Act of the state of Illinois. 
E.  Whenever the village or the Lake County health authority finds that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health or safety, it may without notice or hearing issue an order reciting the existence of such an emergency and requiring that such action be taken as it may deem necessary to meet the emergency. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter, such order shall be effective immediately. Any person to whom such an order is directed shall comply therewith immediately, but upon petition to the ZBA shall be afforded a hearing as soon as possible. The provisions of subsections C and D of this section shall be applicable to such hearing and the order issued thereafter. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 §§ 5.1-5.5) 
15.40.070 - Environmental, open space and access requirements. 
A.  General Requirements. Condition of soil, ground water level, drainage and topography shall not create hazards to the property or the health or safety of the occupants. The site shall not be exposed to objectionable smoke, noise, odors or other adverse influences, and no portion subject to flooding, subsidence or erosion shall be use for any purpose which would expose persons or property to hazards. 
B.  Soil and Ground Cover Requirements. Exposed ground surfaces in all parts of every recreational vehicle park shall be paved, or covered with stone screenings, or other solid material or protected with a vegetative growth that is capable of preventing soil erosion and of eliminating objectionable dust. 
C.  Site Drainage Requirements. The ground surface in all parts of every recreational vehicle park shall be graded and equipped to drain all surface water in a safe, efficient manner. 
D.  Plans submitted for approval: 
1.  Site plan showing all paved and group camping areas; 
2.  Engineering plans and calculations showing storm water runoff (quantity and point or area of departure) prior to and subsequent to construction of the proposed park shall be in compliance with the Lake County on-site detention regulation; 
3.  Erosion control and landscaping plans; 
4.  Sewer and water plans; 
5.  Road and street engineering plans; 
6.  Pet exercise and sanitation areas. 
E.  Recreational Vehicle Parks and Lots, Density Controls, Stands and Group Camping. 
1.  The minimum area for each recreational vehicle park shall be twenty (20) acres. The minimum number of spaces completed and ready for the occupancy before first occupancy is permitted shall be twenty (20) percent of the total spaces proposed to be developed. This subdivision shall not apply to any state licensed recreational area in existence on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
2.  Every recreational vehicle shall be located on a lot having the following minimum area exclusive of park street: area, one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet. 
a.  No recreational vehicle park shall have an overall density greater than eighteen (18) recreational vehicles and tents per gross acre. 
b.  No recreational vehicle park shall have more than two tents permitted on any one stand. 
3.  Required Separation Between Recreational Vehicles. 
a.  Recreational vehicles shall be separated from neighboring units and from buildings and structures by at least ten (10) feet, which shall be maintained unobstructed. 
b.  Accessory buildings shall be separated from recreational vehicles, tents and all other buildings and structures by at least four feet and shall be located no closer than five feet from any lot line. Accessory buildings shall in no case intrude upon the unobstructed area by subsection (E)(3)(a) of this section. 
4.  Stands. The area of the stand shall provide adequate support for the placement of a recreational vehicle. 
    The stand shall not heave, shift or settle unevenly under the weight of the recreational vehicle due to frost action, inadequate drainage, vibration or other forces acting on the structure. 
5.  Group Camping. Group camping areas may be permitted if such areas have been identified in the application for license and permits and meets the following standards: 
a.  Group camping areas shall contain at least one acre in area. 
b.  Group camping areas shall contain at least one toilet facility conveniently located. 
c.  Group camping areas shall not contain more than forty (40) recreational vehicles and/or tents. 
d.  In group camping areas only, there may be more than one recreational vehicle and/or tent located on any lot. 
e.  In group camping areas all recreational vehicle equipped for electrical service shall be required to use park service in lieu of other portable or self-contained power supply sources. 
f.  Group camping areas shall not be permitted within seventy-five (75) feet of any park boundary. 
F.  Required Recreation Areas. 
1.  In all recreational vehicle parks there shall be one or more recreation areas which shall be easily accessible to all park residents. 
2.  Twenty (20) percent of the gross site area shall be provided for recreational areas, generally provided in centralized locations, or in areas with natural recreational amenities and shall include suitable landscaping. In larger parks, greater decentralization will be allowed. Recreation areas may include space for community buildings and/or community use facilities, such as adult recreation, children playgrounds and natural open space. 
3.  Recreational areas shall be so located as to be free of traffic hazards and should, where the topography permits, be centrally located. 
G.  Required Setbacks, Buffer Strips and Screening. 
1.  All recreational vehicles and tents shall not be located along park boundaries so as to cause an adverse impact to adjoining properties. If such adverse impact is probable, a fifty (50) foot setback or greater shall be imposed with a reasonable increase in plantings and/or berms as identified in Appendix A, attached to the ordinance codified in this chapter, which shall be required in order to lessen the impact to adjoining properties affected. 
2.  All recreational vehicles and tents shall be located at least ten (10) feet from a minor street and twenty-five (25) feet from a collector street or entrance street. 
3.  All recreational vehicles and tents shall be located at least twenty (20) feet from any body of water. 
4.  Adequate screening shall be provided along the boundaries and public roads adjoining the site. Planting along the boundary and public roads shall be of a type of material listed in Appendix A, attached to the ordinance codified in this chapter. However, upon review of the plans submitted, the department may waive this requirement if, upon site inspection, sufficient natural planting exists along the boundary and/or public roads to provide suitable screening. 
H.  Park Street System. 
1.  General Requirements. All recreational vehicle parks shall be provided with safe and convenient vehicular access from abutting public streets or roads to each lot. Such access shall be provided by streets, driveways or other means. No on-street parking shall be allowed. 
2.  Access. All recreational vehicle parks shall be provided with safe and convenient vehicular access from an improved public street. It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to provide the necessary access in all cases where there is no existing improved street or road connecting the recreational vehicle park site with an improved existing public street or road. Any street or road improvement required on or beyond the boundary of the recreational vehicle park shall be improved in accordance with the standards of the village subdivision regulations. The State Highway Department shall approve all access and entrance locations and improvements before the issuance of a permit. 
3.  Park Entrance. Entrances to recreational vehicle parks shall be designed to minimize congestion and hazards and allow free movement of traffic on adjacent streets. All park entrance streets shall be a minimum of twenty-four (24) feet in width to their first point of intersection with a minor park street. 
4.  Collector Streets. Collector streets shall have a minimum improved roadway of not less than twenty-four (24) feet in width. 
5.  Minor Streets. Minor streets shall have a minimum improved roadway of not less than eighteen (18) feet in width. 
6.  Culs-de-sac. Culs-de-sac shall not exceed a length of four hundred fifty (450) feet and shall have a terminus generally circular in shape with a diameter of eighty (80) feet. 
7.  Street Construction and Design Standards. 
a.  Entrance and Collector Streets. All entrance streets shall be paved with an A-3 bituminous surface. All entrance and collector streets shall be constructed with a ten (10) inch gravel base, and shall be durable and well-drained under normal use and weather conditions. Pavement edges shall be protected to prevent raveling and wearing of the surface and shifting of the pavement base. Street surfaces shall be maintained free of cracks, holes and other hazards. 
b.  Minor Streets. All minor streets shall be improved with a minimum of an eight-inch rolled and compacted gravel road with a seal coat to reduce dust. Minor streets shall be well-drained under normal use and weather conditions, and where necessary, appropriate precautions shall be taken to prevent road surface erosion. Streets shall be maintained free of ruts, holes, standing water and other hazards. 
c.  Grades. Grades of all streets shall be sufficient to insure adequate surface drainage, but shall be not more than eight percent. Short runs with a maximum grade of twelve (12) percent may be permitted, provided traffic safety is assured by appropriate paving, erosion control, adequate leveling areas and avoidance of lateral curves. 
I.  Car Parking. Off street parking areas shall be provided for the use of park occupants and guests. 
    Parking spaces shall be provided for not less than 1.25 cars per recreational vehicle lot. Required parking spaces include one car space on a recreational vehicle lot, and in addition shall include a sufficient number of parking spaces either off-street or on-street to bring the total number of parking spaces up to the required 1.25 car spaces per lot. 
    A maximum of twenty (20) percent of the required parking spaces may be placed within the setback from the park property boundary provided parking is properly screened. Each such parking space shall be not less than ten (10) feet wide and twenty (20) feet deep, and shall be surfaced for its entire area with a dust palliative. 
J.  Vehicle Traffic Control. 
1.  Parks shall have adequate speed limit signs posted not exceeding fifteen (15) miles per hour. 
2.  Traffic control signs shall be installed to provide standard vehicle and pedestrian safety. 
K.  Walks. 
1.  General Requirements. All parks may be provided with safe, convenient, pedestrian access of adequate width for intended use, durable and convenient to maintain between individual lots, the park streets and all community facilities provided for park occupants. Sudden changes in alignment and gradient shall be avoided. 
2.  Common Walk System. A common walk system may be provided and maintained between locations where pedestrian traffic is concentrated and if provided, shall be designed to provide pedestrian access to all recreation areas and service buildings. Such common walks shall have a minimum width of four feet and shall be of an all-weather surface. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 §§ 7.1-7.11) 
15.40.080 - Water supply. 
A.  General Requirements. An accessible, adequate, safe and potable supply of water shall be provided in each recreational vehicle park. Where a public supply of water of satisfactory quantity, quality and pressure is available at the site or at the boundary of the site, connection shall be made thereto and its supply used exclusively. 
B.  New Water System. When an existing satisfactory public water supply is not available, a new water system may be developed in accordance with the following: 
    The water system, including the supply, storage and distribution facilities, shall be designed in accordance with the public water supply standards and regulations of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. Plans and specifications shall be submitted to the health authority for their approval prior to the issuance of a permit as provided in Section 15.40.020. 
C.  Approval of Drawings. All engineering drawings and specifications for the construction of the system shall be submitted to the village board for review and approval prior to the issuance of permit. 
D.  Individual Water-Riser Pipes and Connections. 
1.  Any recreational vehicle which is equipped for water connection and which occupies a lot providing proper connection, may be connected to the recreational vehicle park's water supply. 
2.  Individual water-riser pipes shall be located within the confined area of the recreational vehicle stand at a point where the water connection will approximate a vertical position. 
3.  Water-riser pipes shall extend at least twelve (12) inches above ground elevation. The pipe shall be at least one-half inch (i.p.s.). 
4.  Adequate provisions shall be made to prevent freezing of service lines, valves and riser pipes and to protect risers from heaving and thawing actions of ground during freezing weather. Surface drainage shall be diverted from the location of the riser pipe. 
5.  A shutoff valve below the frost line shall be provided on each water line. 
6.  Underground step and waste shall not be installed on any water service. 
E.  Common Water Supply. 
1.  Adequate water for drinking and culinary purposes shall be provided at easily accessible locations within each area of unimproved lots, and shall be provided by means of community outlets, faucets and if desired, fountains. Common drinking cups at any such locations shall be prohibited. 
2.  Centralized water supply outlets shall be provided to provide an adequate source of water to permit safe and sanitary recharge of water storage tanks in such recreational vehicles which may contain them. 
3.  An adequate supply of water safe for drinking, showers, bathing and laundering shall be provided to each service building containing any of these facilities. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 §§ 8.1-8.5) 
15.40.090 - Sewage disposal. 
A.  General Requirements. An adequate and safe sewerage system shall be provided in all recreational vehicle parks for the conveying, treatment and disposing of all sewage. Where a public sewerage system of adequate capacity is available at the site or within one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet of the boundary of the site, connection shall be made thereto. 
B.  New Sewerage System. When an existing satisfactory public sewerage system is not available, a sewerage system in conjunction with a private treatment plant may be developed in accordance with the following: 
    The proposed system, including the collection, treatment, if appropriate, and disposal facilities shall be designed in accordance with the standards and regulations of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. Plans and specifications shall be submitted to the Lake County health authority and the village board for its approval prior to the issuance of a permit as provided in Section 15.40.020. 
C.  Sanitary Stations. At least one sanitary station shall be provided in each recreational vehicle park. Sanitary stations shall be located at sites readily accessible to all park occupants and shall be approved in design and operation by the health authority prior to the issuance of a permit as provided in Section 15.40.020. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 §§ 9.1-9.3) 
15.40.100 - Electrical distribution system and telephone service. 
A.  General Requirements. Every park shall contain an electrical wiring system consisting of wiring, fixtures, equipment and appurtenances which shall be installed and maintained in accordance with the National Electric Code. 
B.  Power Distribution Lines. 
1.  All electrical service shall be located underground. 
2.  All direct burial conductors or cable shall be buried at least eighteen (18) inches below the ground surface and shall be insulated and specially designed for the purpose. Such conductors or cable shall be located not less than eighteen (18) inches radial distance from water or sewer. 
C.  Individual Electrical Connections. 
1.  Each improved recreational vehicle lot shall be provided with an approved disconnecting device and over-current protective equipment. This equipment shall be installed between three and five feet above ground and shall be contained in a tamper-proof box and grounded at premises. The minimum service shall be one hundred twenty-five (125) volts AC, twenty (20) amperes, two pole-three wire, grounding type and thirty (30) amperes, two pole-three wire grounding type. 
2.  Outlets (receptacles or pressure connectors) shall be housed in a weatherproof outlet box, and shall be located not more than fifty (50) feet from the over-current protective device in the recreational vehicle, as measured from the recreational vehicle to a lot line and thence along lot lines to the outlet. A three-pole, three wire grounding type shall be used as a minimum standard. 
3.  Receptacles, if provided, shall be in accordance with American Standard Outlet Receptacle. 
4.  All recreational vehicles which are equipped for electrical connection, may be connected to the available outlet box. Such connection shall be made by means of an approved type of flexible supply cord with a male attachment plug or with pressure connectors. When the distance from the recreational vehicle to an available outlet box exceeds 26.5 feet, supply cords shall be placed and secured along lot lines from the outlet box to a point at right angles to the point of connection to the recreational vehicle and from there to the recreational vehicle. (See Group Camping, Section 15.40.070(E)(5)(e).) 
D.  Telephone Service. A reasonable number of telephones shall be available at easily accessible locations within the park. The telephone numbers of the local police, state police, fire department, ambulance service and local hospital shall be posted and maintained in a conspicuous place near each telephone. These may be coin-operated public phones. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 §§ 10.1-10.4) 
15.40.110 - Refuse handling. 
A.  The storage, collection and disposal of refuse in the recreational vehicle park shall be so conducted as to create no health hazards, rodent harborage, insect breeding areas, accident or fire hazards or air pollution. 
B.  All refuse shall be stored in flytight, watertight, rodentproof containers. Such containers shall be provided in sufficient number and capacity to properly store all refuse. 
C.  The burning of refuse, garbage trash or natural waste and grass clippings is specifically prohibited. All such wastes shall be removed from the recreational vehicle park as provided above and disposed of in a properly licensed refuse disposal site. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 §§ 11.1-11.3) 
15.40.120 - Service buildings and other community facilities. 
A.  General Requirements. The requirements of this section shall apply to service buildings, recreation buildings and other community service facilities such as: 
1.  Management offices, repair shops for park equipment and storage areas; 
2.  Sanitary facilities; 
3.  Laundry facilities; 
4.  Indoor recreation areas; 
5.  Commercial uses supplying goods or services for the exclusive use of park occupants, provided no signs or visible advertising of any kind is permitted to accompany such uses; 
6.  Food services for the exclusive use of park occupants, provided no signs or visible advertising of any kind is permitted to accompany such uses. 
B.  Management Residences. Each recreational vehicle park may have a maximum of two detached dwellings and no mobilehomes for residential purposes of the owner and/or manager. 
C.  Structural Requirements for Buildings. 
1.  All service buildings, recreational buildings and attached residential quarters shall be constructed to meet applicable requirements of the BOCA Building Code. 
2.  Recreational vehicles, as defined in this chapter, shall not be used for accessory purposes in connection with any park. 
3.  All portions of the structure shall be properly protected from damage by ordinary use and by decay, corrosion, termites, rodents and other destructive elements. Exterior portions shall be of such materials and be so constructed and protected as to prevent entrance or penetration of moisture and weather. 
4.  All rooms containing sanitary or laundry facilities shall: 
a.  Have sound-resistant walls extending to the ceiling between male and female sanitary facilities. Walls and partitions around showers, bathtubs, lavatories and other plumbing fixtures shall be constructed of dense, non-absorbent, waterproof material or covered with moisture-proof material; 
b.  Have at least two windows or skylights facing directly to the outdoors. The minimum aggregate gross area of windows for each required room shall not be less than ten (10) percent of the floor area served by them; 
c.  Have at least one window which can be easily opened, or a mechanical device which will adequately ventilate the room. 
5.  Toilets shall be located in separate compartments equipped with self-closing doors; shower stalls shall be of the individual type, each with a separate dressing compartment. The rooms shall be screened to prevent direct view of the interior when the exterior doors are open and all floors shall be slip-proof. One toilet and low sink shall be provided for handicapped individuals. 
6.  Illumination levels shall be maintained as follows: 
a.  General seeing tasks: five foot candles; 
b.  Laundry room work area: forty (40) foot candles; 
c.  Toilet room, in front of mirrors: forty (40) foot candles. 
7.  Hot and cold water shall be furnished to every lavatory, sink, bathtub, shower and laundry fixture, and cold water shall be furnished to every water closet and urinal. 
8.  Unless further restricted by this chapter, all service buildings and sanitary and laundry facilities contained therein must meet the minimum requirements of the state of Illinois Department of Public Health Rules and Regulations for recreational areas. 
D.  Barbecue Pits, Fireplaces, Stoves and Incinerators. Cooking shelters, barbecue pits, fireplaces and woodburning stoves shall be so located, constructed, maintained and used as to minimize fire hazards and smoke nuisance both on the property on which used and on neighboring property. No open fire shall be permitted except in appropriate locations and facilities provided. No fuel shall be used and no material burned which emits dense smoke or objectionable odors. 
E.  Food Services. 
1.  Food preparation and distribution facilities are to be constructed and furnished in accordance with the regulations of the health authority and the village fire department. 
2.  Food services shall be solely for the park occupants and/or employees of the park. 
3.  All prepared foods shall be sold for consumption within the park. 
4.  Park management shall not advertise nor offer food services to anyone not considered an occupant or employee of the park. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 §§ 12.1-12.5) 
15.40.130 - Insect and rodent control. 
A.  Grounds, buildings and structures shall be maintained free of insect and rodent harborage and infestation. Extermination methods and other measures to control insects and rodents shall conform with the requirements of the health authority. 
B.  Parks shall be maintained free of accumulations of debris which may provide rodent harborage or breeding places for flies, mosquitoes and other pests. 
C.  Where the potential for insect and rodent infestation exists, all exterior openings in or beneath any permanent structure shall be appropriately screened with wire mesh or other suitable materials. 
D.  The growth of brush, weeds and grass shall be controlled to prevent harborage of ticks, chiggers and other noxious insects. Parks shall be so maintained as to prevent the growth of ragweed, poison ivy, poison oak, poison sumac and other noxious weeds considered detrimental to health. Open areas shall be maintained free of heavy undergrowth of any description. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 §§ 13.1-13.4) 
15.40.140 - Fire protection. 
A.  Recreational vehicle parks shall be kept free of litter, rubbish and other flammable material. 
B.  Portable fire extinguishers rated for Class B and C fires shall be kept in service buildings, conveniently and readily accessible for use by all occupants. The locations and type required shall be approved by the village fire department. 
C.  1.  When community water and storage facilities are available, fire hydrants shall be installed in accordance with the following minimum requirements: 
a.  The water supply system shall permit the operation of a minimum of two one and one-half inch hose streams. 
b.  Each of two nozzles, held four feet above the ground, shall deliver at least seventy-five (75) gallons of water per minute at a flowing pressure of at least thirty (30) pounds per square inch at the highest elevation point of the park. 
c.  Dry hydrant location shall be located as recommended by the fire department. 
2.  Fire hydrants shall be located within five hundred (500) feet of any recreational vehicle, tent, service building or other structure in the park. 
D.  Fire extinguishers shall be kept in working condition. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 §§ 14.1-14.4) 
15.40.150 - Miscellaneous requirements. 
A.  Responsibilities of the Park Management. 
1.  The person to whom a license for a recreational vehicle park is issued shall operate the park in compliance with this chapter and shall provide adequate supervision to maintain the park, its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition. 
2.  The park management shall give to each park registrant a copy of subsection B of this section for their inspection and may offer other applicable provisions of this chapter. 
3.  The park management shall maintain a register containing the names of all park occupants. Such register shall be available to any authorized person inspecting the park. 
4.  The park management shall notify the health authority immediately of any suspected communicable or contagious disease within the park. 
5.  The park management shall be responsible for controlling noise within the park to levels where park occupants and adjoining property owners are not disturbed. 
6.  Public park management shall not offer for lease or rent any recreational vehicles. However, membership park management may own single-family recreational vehicles and offer to lease them back to the membership. The vehicles shall be retained in a mobile condition and at no time be placed on a permanent foundation or offered for public lease or rental. 
B.  Responsibilities of the Park Occupants. 
1.  The park occupant shall comply with all applicable requirements of this chapter and shall maintain his or her lot, its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition. 
2.  The park occupant shall be responsible for proper placement of his or her recreational vehicle on its stand or his or her tent in its proper location, and proper installation of any utility connections in accordance with the instructions of the park management. 
3.  Pets, if permitted in the park, shall be prohibited from running at large or committing any nuisance. 
4.  The park occupant shall store and dispose of all his or her rubbish and garbage in a clean, sanitary and safe manner in containers. 
5.  Fire extinguisher for Class B and C fires shall be kept at the premises of each recreational vehicle and maintained in working condition. 
6.  The park occupant shall be responsible for controlling noise within the park to levels where he does not disturb other park occupants. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 §§ 15.1, 15.2) 
15.40.160 - Interpretation of provisions. 
    In any case where a provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict with a provision of any other ordinance or code of the village on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, the provision which, in the judgment of the village, establishes the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people shall prevail. In any case where a provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict with a provision of any other ordinance or code of the village on the effective date of said ordinance which establishes a lower standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people, the provision of this chapter shall be deemed to prevail, and such other ordinances or codes are declared to be repealed to the extent that they may be found in conflict with this chapter. 
(Ord. 84-O-2 § 17.1) 
Chapter 15.44 - FIRE CODE ADOPTED

    That a certain document being marked and designated as the International Fire Code, 2018 Edition, as published by the International Code Council, be and is adopted as the Fire Code of the Village of Round Lake, in the state of Illinois for regulations affecting or relating to structures, processes, premises and safeguards regarding all of the following: The hazard of fire and explosion arising from the storage, handling or use of structures, materials or devises. Conditions hazardous to life, property or public welfare in the occupancy of structures or premises. Fire hazards in the structure or on the premises from occupancy or operation. Matters related to the construction, extension, repair, alteration or removal of fire suppression or alarm systems. Conditions affecting the safety of fire fighters and emergency responders during emergency operations. Providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Fire Code on file in the office of the Village of Round Lake are referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, as prescribed in this chapter.

Chapter 15.60 - RESIDENTIAL RENTAL PROPERTY REGISTRATION AND INSPECTION 
Sections: 

15.60.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the registration and inspection of residential rental property so as to protect the health, safety and welfare of the people of the village, and to facilitate the enforcement of minimum standards for maintenance, while preserving character and property values throughout the village. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-30, § 1, 10-15-18) 
15.60.020 - Definitions. 
    Unless the context shall otherwise require, terms used in this chapter shall have the definitions given in this section or in property maintenance code, of Chapter 15.28 of the village Code. 
    "Agent" or "Representative": Any person or firm, acting for another, with authority to rent, manage and/ or make expenditures. 
    "Dwelling Unit": Any rooms or group of rooms located within a dwelling and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
    "Multi-Family Building Common Areas": Any part of a building or property, not exclusively available to an individual tenant, including, but not limited to, building exterior, yard, basement, stairway, laundry facility, lobby, mailroom, or roof. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-30, § 1, 10-15-18) 
15.60.030 - Registration required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, trust, partnership, association, corporation, or other legal entity to lease or allow occupancy of any rental dwelling unit, within the corporate limits of the village without registering the unit. 
A.  Registration. The registration period shall run from February 1st to January 31st. Registration shall be required annually and shall be completed prior to February 1st of each year thereafter, regardless of its initial registration date. 
B.  Registration shall be on a form provided by the village, which shall be filled out in its entirety, truthfully and accurately. The following shall be provided by the applicant: 
1.  The address of the dwelling unit to be occupied; 
2.  The number of separate dwelling units within the premises; 
3.  The full legal name, address, telephone numbers (home, mobile and work) and email address of each and every owner; 
4.  Name and contact information for agent or representative of the owner, where applicable; and 
5.  The total square footage designed for living and sleeping purposes within the building or premises to be occupied. 
C.  Change in registration information. The property owner of a rental unit, registered with the village, shall re-register within thirty (30) days after any change occurs in registration information. Registration and/or inspection fees shall not apply. 
D.  Transfer. Unless otherwise provided, no residential rental certificate of compliance shall be transferable or assignable. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-30, § 1, 10-15-18) 
15.60.040 - Certificate of compliance required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, trust, partnership, association, corporation, or other legal entity to lease or allow occupancy of any rental dwelling unit, within the corporate limits of the village without obtaining a residential rental certificate of compliance. 
A.  A residential rental certificate of compliance shall be required for each residential dwelling unit that is occupied solely by person(s) not holding the title to the dwelling unit and/or not residing in the dwelling unit with one holding the title to the dwelling unit as his/her principal residence. The certificate of compliance shall be issued only after both of the following are completed: 
1.  Registration of the rental unit with the community development department; and 
2.  Inspection by the village building official or designee, demonstrating compliance with all ordinances adopted by the village and state law. 
B.  Validity. Once a certificate of compliance is issued, it shall be valid and continued until the sooner of any of the following occurs: 
1.  The current occupant(s) vacate the residential dwelling unit; or 
2.  The certificate of compliance is lawfully revoked or suspended. 
C.  A residential rental certificate of compliance is not required for: 
1.  Property owners renting to a family member; or 
2.  Property owners who rent their dwelling unit for less than one hundred twenty (120) consecutive days but occupy the dwelling unit during the remainder of the year; or 
3.  Individuals who live in a property owned by a trust when they are the beneficiaries of that trust, or family members of the beneficiaries of that trust. 
D.  Requirements pursuant to this section shall not be applicable to group homes governed by the specialized living centers act, 405 Illinois Compiled Statutes 25/1 et seq., as amended, for the developmentally disabled, or to other similar uses governed by federal or state laws, rules or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-30, § 1, 10-15-18) 
15.60.050 - Fees. 
    A schedule of fees in accordance with the provisions of this section shall be as set forth in Title 20 of this Code, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-30, § 1, 10-15-18; Ord. No. 18-O-38, § 16, 12-17-2018) 
15.60.060 - Inspections. 
A.  The village shall utilize the property maintenance code, of Chapter 15.28 of the village Code and other applicable ordinance regulations, as adopted and amended by the board of trustees, as the established standards for the inspection of residential rental dwelling structures and units. 
B.  For each dwelling unit, inspection shall be made to obtain and maintain compliance with the standards of this article based upon any one of the following: 
1.  Upon vacancy of a dwelling unit; 
2.  A complaint received by the village indicating that there is a violation of the standards or the provisions of the ordinances adopted by the village; 
3.  An observation by the village of a violation of the standards or the provisions of the ordinances adopted by the village; or 
4.  A request for an inspection by the property owner. 
C.  For each multi-family building, inspection of all common areas shall be made annually. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-30, § 1, 10-15-18) 
15.60.070 - Minimum standards. 
    No residential rental dwelling unit shall be occupied or continued to be occupied unless the structure in which said unit is located complies with the provisions and standards of the property maintenance code adopted by the village, and is maintained in a structurally sound condition and kept free from health, fire and other hazards to life and property. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-30, § 1, 10-15-18) 
15.60.080 - No warranty of habitability. 
    The issuance of a certificate of compliance shall not be construed as a warranty of habitability of the dwelling unit. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as creating a duty or obligation of the village or its code official or agents and employees to any individual certificate holder or occupant of or visitor to a rental dwelling. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-30, § 1, 10-15-18) 
15.60.090 - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm, company, corporation or any agent, employees or contractors of such who shall violate, disobey, omit, neglect or refuse to comply with or resist enforcement of any provision of this title shall be fined not less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-30, § 1, 10-15-18) 
15.60.100 - Revocation. 
    If the building official, or designee, shall discover the failure of any property owner to comply with a notice of violation issued pursuant to the provisions of the ordinances adopted by the village, the certificate of compliance may be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-30, § 1, 10-15-18) 
Chapter 15.64 - FORECLOSURE AND VACANT PROPERTY REGISTRATION PROGRAM 
Sections: 

15.64.010 - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish a registration program as a mechanism to help protect neighborhoods from becoming blighted through the lack of adequate maintenance of properties that are in default or defaulted, and to provide a mechanism to avert foreclosure actions through timely intervention, education, or counseling of property owners. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-34, § 1, 11-19-2018) 
15.64.020 - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    "Default" shall mean that the mortgagor has not complied with the terms of the mortgage on the property, or the promissory note, or other evidence of the debt, referred to in the mortgage. 
    "Enforcement officer" shall mean any law enforcement officer, building official, code enforcement officer, fire inspector, building inspector, or other person authorized by the village to enforce the applicable code(s). 
    "Evidence of vacancy" shall mean any condition that on its own, or combined with other conditions present, would lead a reasonable person to believe that the property is vacant. Such conditions may include, but are not limited to: overgrown and/or dead vegetation; past due utility notices and/or disconnected utilities; accumulation of trash, junk or debris; abandoned vehicles, auto parts and/or materials; the absence of furnishings and/or personal items consistent with habitation or occupancy; the presence of an unsanitary, stagnant swimming pool; the accumulation of newspapers, circulars, flyers and/or mail; statements by neighbors, passers-by, delivery agents or government agents; and/or the presence of boards over doors, windows or other openings in violation of applicable code. 
    "Foreclosure or foreclosure action" shall mean the legal process by which a mortgagee, or other lien holder, terminates or attempts to terminate a property owner's equitable right of redemption to obtain legal and equitable title to the real property pledged as security for a debt or the real property subject to the lien. The legal process is not concluded until the property obtained by the mortgagee, lien holder, or their designee, by certificate of title, or any other means, is sold to a non-related bona fide purchaser in an arm's length transaction to satisfy the debt or lien. 
    "Mortgagee" shall mean the creditor, including but not limited to, trustees; mortgage servicing companies; lenders in a mortgage agreement; any agent, servant, or employee of the creditor; any successor in interest; or any assignee of the creditor's rights, interests or obligations under the mortgage agreement; or any other person or entity with the legal right to foreclose on the real property, excluding governmental entities. 
    "Owner" shall mean every person, entity, or mortgagee, who alone or severally with others, has legal or equitable title to any real property as defined by this chapter; has legal care, charge, or control of any such property; is in possession or control of any such property; and/or is vested with possession or control of any such property. The property manager shall not be considered the owner. 
    "Property manager" shall mean any party designated by the owner as responsible for inspecting, maintaining and securing the property as required in this chapter. 
    "Real property" shall mean any residential or commercial land and/or buildings, leasehold improvements and anything affixed to the land, or portion thereof identified by a property parcel identification number. 
    "Registrable property" shall mean: 
(a)  Any real property located in the village, whether vacant or occupied, that is encumbered by a mortgage in default, is subject to an ongoing foreclosure action by the mortgagee or trustee, has been the subject of a foreclosure action by a mortgagee or trustee and a judgement has been entered, or has been the subject of a foreclosure sale where the title was transferred to the beneficiary of a mortgage involved in the foreclosure and any properties transferred under a deed in lieu of foreclosure/sale. The designation of a "default/foreclosure" property as "registrable" shall remain in place until such time as the property is sold to a non-related bona fide purchaser in an arm's length transaction or the foreclosure action has been dismissed and any default on the mortgage has been cured; or 
(b)  Any property that is vacant for more than thirty (30) days or any cancellation of utility or service, whichever occurs first. 
    "Semi-annual registration" shall mean six (6) months from the date of the first action that requires registration, or its designee, and every subsequent six (6) months. The date of the initial registration may be different than the date of the first action that required registration. 
    "Utilities and services" shall mean any utility and/or service that is essential for a building to be habitable and/or perform a service necessary to comply with all village codes. This includes, but is not limited to, electrical, gas, water, sewer, lawn maintenance, pool maintenance, and snow removal. 
    "Vacant" shall mean any parcel of land that contains any building or structure that is not lawfully occupied. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-34, § 1, 11-19-2018) 
15.64.030 - Establishment of a registry. 
    There is hereby established a registry, cataloging each registrable property containing the information required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 18-O-34, § 1, 11-19-2018) 
15.64.040 - Inspection and registration of defaulted mortgage.
