    Any such repair or maintenance costs or snow and ice removal costs may be charged to the subdivider's letter of credit, cash or other security. 
2.  Filing of Maintenance Retention or Guarantee. 
a.  The subdivider shall file a maintenance letter of credit, bonds, cash or other security with an automatic renewal with the village prior to the dedication of the improvements, in an amount no less than ten (10) percent of the total improvement cost and in a form satisfactory to the village attorney, in order to assure the satisfactory condition of the required improvements for a period of one year after the date of their acceptance by the village board. The maintenance bond shall continue in effect for good cause shown in writing by the village beyond the maintenance period and until the village staff shall verify that condition of the improvements is satisfactory and recommend release of the maintenance bond. 
b.  The village shall retain a portion of the letter of credit, cash, or other securities, posted in conformance with subsection A.3.a. of this section, equal to five percent of the total cost of the accepted improvements. This guarantee shall be retained for a period of one year after the date of the acceptance of the dedicated improvements by the village board. During this period, the funds shall be used to pay for the cost of any repairs to the accepted improvements not paid for by the subdivider. At the end of the period, any remaining unused funds shall be returned to the subdivider. 
c.  The final release of the sum of five percent of the original letter of credit or alternate security less any costs of repairs covering a subdivision's improvement work held for the one-year guarantee period will be predicated upon an inspection of all improvements including a leak detection test of the subdivision's water main segments, and electronic inspection of all sanitary sewer mains. 
    The water main test will be performed by an approved qualified leak detection specialist. The test results will be forwarded to the village engineer for final determination of an acceptable level of leakage. The village engineer will then, based on the test results, recommend the final release of the remaining letter of credit sum still being held for water main guarantee. 
E.  Cost of Improvements to the Village. 
1.  Required Improvements at Subdivider's Expense. All costs related to the construction and installation of the required improvements shall be borne by the subdivider, and the improvements shall be dedicated to the village without charge. 
2.  Over-Sized Improvements. Wherever necessary to conform to the comprehensive plan of the village, or otherwise to protect or promote the public interest, the village may require that the required improvements be over-sized. The cost to construct and install such over-sized facilities by the subdivider shall be no greater than that which would result from the construction and installation of improvements sized for the subdivision. The excess cost resulting from the requirement of over-sizing the improvements shall be borne by such party or parties as specified by the village board at the time of approval of the detailed engineering drawings, which could include, but not be limited to the following: 
a.  Other affected property owners in a recapture ordinance. 
b.  Other appropriate public authority. 
c.  By means of an abatement of a portion for the required tap-on fees and charges. 
d.  The village. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.802) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
Chapter 16.20 - ENGINEERING SPECIFICATIONS 
Sections: 

16.20.010 - Compliance required. 
A.  The owner or subdivider shall install storm and sanitary sewer, water supply, street grading and pavement, alleys, street lighting, pavement striping, and street signs in accordance with applicable ordinances and standards of construction of the village. 
B.  No subdivision of land or individual lot development shall be approved without a statement signed by the design engineer certifying that the improvements described in the subdivider's plans and specifications, together with any other agreements, meet the minimum requirements of all ordinances of the village. 
C.  The construction of improvements required by these regulations shall be in accordance with and to the specifications set forth hereunder, and unless otherwise specified, all construction work shall be done in accordance with the provisions of the Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction by the Department of Transportation, state of Illinois and their revisions and additions as adopted from time to time; the Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois, current edition, as well as all current village construction standards. In case of conflict, village standards will govern. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.600) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.20.020 - Sanitary sewers. 
A.  General Requirements. All public, private and individual sanitary facilities shall be constructed in accordance with the following publications, or the latest revisions thereof. In case of conflicting standards, the more stringent standards shall apply: 
1.  Standard Specification for Water Sewer Main Construction in Illinois, current edition, published by the Illinois Society of Professional Engineers, et al. 
2.  Recommended Standards for Sewage Works, current edition, prepared by the Great Lakes Upper Mississippi River Board of State Sanitary Engineers. 
B.  Requirements of Other Public Bodies. All facilities must meet the requirements of the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, Illinois Department of Public Health, and Lake County Health department, Lake County Department of Public Works, the Round Lake Sanitary District, or Lakes Region Sanitary District, where applicable, and the Fox Lake Northwest Regional Wastewater Reclamation Facility. 
C.  Specific Requirements. 
1.  General. Sanitary sewer and services of approved design and capacity, with a minimum earth cover of six feet, shall be provided to serve all lots and to provide for the reasonable expansions of the system in the future. Sanitary sewer manholes shall be located at points which will minimize the possibility of submergence in storms. 
2.  Materials. Polyvinylchloride (PVC) SDR 26 up to eighteen (18) inches diameter or other acceptable materials under proper and industry standard usage may be used for the sanitary sewer line. Vylon or other ribbed PVC subject to approval of village/engineer may be an alternative for diameters over eighteen (18) inches. The village engineer may prohibit the use of any of these materials where its application may result in excessive infiltration, short service life of the pipe, or other deleterious effects. 
3.  Infiltration Control. Sanitary sewers shall be constructed to minimize infiltration. Where infiltration potential may exist, such items as watertight manholes, waterproof membranes, factory manufactured manhole-sewer pipe joints, chimney seals, and the like to attempt to prohibit infiltration. 
4.  Building Service. 
a.  Building services shall be of PVC pipe or other specially approved pipe and shall be extended to within one foot of the property line of the lot being serviced prior to construction of street pavements. The service shall be approximately at the center line of the lot and must be constructed as near as perpendicular to the lot line. 
b.  The size of the service shall be six inches minimum, or larger as determined on the basis of the total number of fixture units drained by them in accordance with the Round Lake plumbing code currently adopted by the village. All services shall be constructed with a factory made connection to the sewer main. All stubs shall be properly plugged to enable passage of an air test. All service locations shall be shown on the "record drawings" for the subdivision. 
5.  Allowable Leakage Test for Sanitary Sewers. Sanitary sewers shall be tested in accordance with the previously referenced Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois, latest edition shall apply. Where the sewer is below the ground water table or when conditions do not permit an air test, an infiltration leakage test may be allowed by the village engineer. The infiltration test shall not exceed two hundred (200) gallons per inch of pipe diameter per mile per day of sewer pipe, including manholes in the test section. All manholes shall be vacuum tested. 
6.  All thermoplastic sanitary sewer pipes shall be deflection tested in accordance with the standard specifications. Additionally all new sewer lines shall be televised prior to be placed into service. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.601) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.20.030 - Storm water control facilities. 
A.  General. 
1.  Adequate provisions shall be made in all subdivisions for the proper drainage of storm water. Drainage inlets shall be provided in gutters, discharging directly into a storm sewer system, which shall carry the storm water to an established watercourse approved by the village board. No increase in storm water runoff shall be directed to an existing watercourse or drainage system unless the village engineer has determined that the receiving watercourse or drainage system shall have adequate capacity to receive such increased flow. Storm water retention facilities may be required on site. All discharge of storm water run-off from a proposed subdivision shall abide by the flood plain regulations of the village and the Lake County Watershed Development Ordinance. 
2.  Best management practices are encouraged. 
B.  Storm Sewers. 
1.  Where storm sewer systems are required by the subdivision control ordinance the storm sewer systems and/or open channels shall be designed to accommodate a storm flow rate of not less than the following computation: 
    The diameter of the storm sewer shall be determined on the basis of "Mannings Formula" with a roughness coefficient for pipe of not less than 0.013. The minimum storm frequency shall be: 
Residential - single-family - low density 10 year Residential - high density 10 year Commercial, Industrial, Offices, Etc. 10 year Detention Basins 100 year  
    More stringent storm frequency criteria may be required in those cases where resulting storm water in excess of the capacity of the storm sewer causes flooding or property damage due to lack of, or inadequacy of, emergency storm water by-pass or overflows. 
    The storm sewers shall be provided to accept and convey all storm waters entering upon the subdivision or lot. They shall be sized to adequately carry storm water to all tributary areas at such time as they are developed to the density shown on the comprehensive plan of the village. 
2.  Inlets shall be placed in the street gutters at all street intersections and elsewhere as required by the terrain and the village engineer, to prevent gutter flow from crossing street intersections, and at all intervals of no more than four hundred (400) feet apart along the gutter. Materials, sewer and manhole arrangement and details of design of all storm drainage facilities shall be subject to the approval of the village engineer. 
    Inlets shall be provided at all low points and all points where the design intensity of flow reaches one cubic foot per second. Parkway inlets shall be provided with a catch basin bottom as shown in the Village details. 
3.  Minimum cover for storm sewers should be four feet, unless special precautions, approved by the village engineer, are taken to protect the pipe. Storm sewers shall be designed to flow full with a minimum velocity of three feet per second and a maximum velocity of ten (10) feet per second. 
4.  Open channels of trapezoidal design may be provided on an optional basis in lieu of enclosed storm sewer pipe where the following conditions are met: 
a.  The channel shall serve as the outlet for enclosed storm sewers from a drainage area of eighty (80) acres or more. 
b.  Side slopes shall be at a ratio of 4:1 or flatter, as approved by the village engineer. 
c.  The open channel shall be fully sodded. 
d.  The channel profile shall not create erosive velocities. 
e.  That the party responsible for maintenance meets the approval of the village board. 
5.  All materials for the construction of bridges, culverts, storm sewers, catch basins, manholes, inlets, and other facilities shall conform to the previously referenced Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction and Highway Standards. Storm sewer material shall be reinforced concrete pipe, Class IV, with rubber gasket joints, ten-inch internal diameter minimum. At the discretion of the village engineer, sump pump collection lines, not considered storm sewers, may use PVC SDR26 pipe, eight-inch minimum diameter. 
C.  Storm Water Detention Facilities with Permanent Standing Water. 
1.  Out-Falls, In-Falls and Spillways. 
a.  Out falls, in-falls and spillways shall be provided as needed, in sizes, numbers and locations to be approved by the village engineer. Public safety and water quality enhancement features shall be considered in the design. 
b.  In-falls shall have concrete headwalls or end sections with broken rip-rap or other soil erosion control material from the edge of the headwall, or end section, to normal water level in the basin pipe or opening. 
c.  Safety screens or other safety devices shall be provided at an opening over twelve (12) inches in a size and type approved by the village engineer. 
2.  Soil Characteristics. 
a.  That portion of the basin below the normal water level shall be lined with clay and/or waterproof membrane as approved by the village engineer to prevent seepage of water from the basin. 
b.  The side slopes of the retention basin shall be compacted with stable material, except that sand and gravel may be used where the slope of the side of the basin, below normal water level, is not greater than six feet horizontal to one foot vertical. 
3.  Landscaping and Improvements. 
a.  Parkways and side slopes of the freeboard area shall be seeded with grass, except for that area around the access point or way to the public right-of-way which shall be treated as required by the village. 
b.  The plan commission may recommend and the village board may require fences, paved walkways, low level lighting, fixed benches, docks, launching areas, gazebos, floored rain shelters, and other items which it determines are necessary for proper safety, use, and enjoyment of the facilities for recreational purposes, in conformance with the requirements of Section 16.16.100. 
4.  Water Level Quality. 
a.  A system of maintaining the water quality shall be provided, which may include a floating pump or other system for aerating the pond. 
b.  The retention area must be on average four to six feet deep with twenty-five (25) percent of the pond ten (10) feet in depth. 
5.  Means of Access. The means of access to a public right-of-way shall be constructed as required by the village board in conformance with recommendations of the village engineer. 
6.  All Other Construction Standards. All other design and construction features of the detention basin shall require the specific approval of the village engineer whose decision may be appealed to the plan commission. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.602) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012)

(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.603)

16.20.050 - Water supply facilities. 
A.  General Requirements. All water supply facilities shall be constructed in accordance with the following publications or the latest revisions thereof. In case of conflicting standards the more stringent standard shall apply, as determined by the village engineer. 
1.  Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois, current edition, published by the Illinois Society of Professional Engineers, et al.; 
2.  Recommended Standards for Water Works, current edition, prepared by the Great Lakes-Upper Mississippi River Board of State Sanitary Engineers; 
3.  Illinois Water Well Construction Code, current edition, State of Illinois, Department of Public Health; 
4.  Guide for Determination of Required Fire Flow, current edition, prepared by Insurance Services Office; as a guide, the minimum fire flow requirements are as follows: 
Land Use Recommended 
Fire Flows 
(GPM) Single-Family Residential 1500 Multiple Family Residential 2500 Commercial/Business (General) 2500 Office/Research 2500 Institutional 2500 General Manufacturing 3000 High-Risk Manufacturing 3500  
5.  Standard Schedule for Grading Cities and Towns of the United States with Reference to Their Fire Defenses and Physical Conditions, published by the National Board of Fire Underwriters, current edition. 
B.  Requirements of Other Public Bodies. Where applicable, all facilities shall meet the requirements of the Illinois Environment Protection Agency, Illinois Department of Public Health, Illinois Department of Mines and Minerals, and Lake County Health Department. 
C.  Specific Requirements. 
1.  Water Mains. 
a.  Water mains shall not be less than eight inches in diameter and shall be designed with two sources in a loop to avoid dead ends where practical. Shut-off valves in vaults shall be provided at each branch main connection and elsewhere as required by the village engineer to permit adequate sectionalizing for maintenance purposes. The design shall provide enough valves to limit the number of single-family residences in a shutdown to no more than twenty-five (25). 
b.  Water mains larger than eight inches in diameter shall be required in business, industrial, and high density residential districts where a fire flow rate in excess of normal residential demands is required. The Guide for Determination of Required Fire Flow, current edition prepared by the Insurance Services Offices and the Standard Schedule for Grading Cities and Towns of the United States with Reference to Their Fire Defenses and Physical Conditions, published by the National Board of Fire Underwriters, current edition, or the latest revisions of these manuals, shall be used to determine required fire flow. The cost of these water mains shall be fully borne by the subdivider. The village shall require the developer to pay for water system modeling, or input of proposed main sizing into an existing village model to verify sufficiency of main size. Any consultant costs incurred by the village shall be covered by the developer's escrow account. 
2.  House Services. A house service connection shall be provided approximately at the centerline of each lot, must be constructed as near as perpendicular to the lot line, and shall be extended to a Buffalo Box before road pavement is laid. The Buffalo Box shall be located per village standard detail. The home service pipe shall be one inch in diameter unless it is over ninety (90) feet. If it is over ninety (90) feet, then the home service pipe shall be a minimum of one and one-half inches in diameter. The copper line shall be continuous, without joints between the main and B-box, and B-box to the meter. The as-built location of all b-boxes shall be shown on the "record drawings" for the subdivision. 
3.  Materials. 
a.  All service pipes which are two inches or less in diameter shall be type K copper tubing from the street main to the water meter. 
b.  Service pipes larger than two inches in internal diameter and all water main shall be ductile iron pipe, with minimum thickness Class 52 and shall conform to ANSI A21.51 shall have an outside bituminous coating of asphalt base and a cement mortar lining conforming to ANSI/AWWA C104/A21.4 and shall be polyethylene wrapped meeting the requirements of ANSI/AWWA A21.5-99/C105. Wrap all water mains, fittings, valves, fire hydrant leaders, fire hydrants, and service lines. 
c.  All joints in ductile iron service pipes shall be of the mechanical or push-on type which shall conform to ANSI/AWWA C111/A21.11. 
d.  All materials and construction standards shall be in accordance with the State of Illinois Plumbing Code or other standards that may be adopted by the village. Water main fittings shall require the use of A-304 stainless steel bolts and nuts and washers of series 300 stainless steel per ASTM A194 for water main fittings. 
e.  Provide restrained type fittings that are compatible with system utilized, as specified by the pipe manufacturer. 
4.  Fire Hydrants. 
a.  The placement and number of fire hydrants shall be in accordance with the hydrant service area schedule stated in the previously referenced Standard Schedule for Grading Cities and Towns of the United States with Reference to Their Fire Defenses and Physical Conditions. In no case shall fire hydrant spacing exceed three hundred (300) feet. Fire hydrants shall be so placed so that they are accessible at all times, and positioned relative to the street curb per the village detail. 
b.  All fire hydrants shall have National Standard Threads. Fire hydrants shall have a five and one-quarter inch value opening and two and two and one-half inch connections and four and one-half inch connection. All valves and fire hydrants shall open counter-clockwise. 
c.  Fire hydrants shall be Mueller manufacture or an equivalent approved by the village engineer with auxiliary valves and boxes (vaults excepted), installed per village standard detail. 
d.  A minimum earth cover of five feet six inches over the top of water mains and services shall be provided. 
e.  Gate valves shall be located in valve vaults. The valve shall be of Mueller 2360 manufacture, or their approved equivalent, installed per village standard detail. 
f.  All fire hydrants shall be painted red with exact paint type and hue to be approved by the director of public works. 
g.  The removal of water from any fire hydrant shall not be permitted unless otherwise approved by director of public works. 
5.  Valve and Vaults. 
a.  Valves twelve (12) inches or smaller shall be full wall ductile iron body, non-rising stem gates valves, modified wedge type conforming to AWWA C509. Valves shall be Mueller 2360, or their approved equivalent, installed per village standard detail. 
b.  Valves larger than twelve (12) inches shall be ductile-iron body, rubber sealed, tight closure butterfly valves conforming to AWWA C-504. Valves shall be Class 150B and shall open counter clockwise and be operated by a two-inch square nut. Valves shall be Mueller Lineseal Series, or their approved equal. 
c.  Valves shall be located on water mains so as to be able to isolate sections of main from the entire system with minimum disruption of service. 
d.  Valves shall be installed so that not over eight hundred (800) feet of water main, with services, will be shut off at any time. 
e.  Valve vaults are required on all valves six inches or larger. Valve vaults shall be minimum of sixty (60) inches inside diameter. 
6.  Tapping Sleeves and Tapping Valves. 
a.  Use a two-piece stainless steel tapping sleeve. Acceptable manufacture is Cascade CST model, extra heavy duty. 
b.  Tapping valve shall be a fully ported gate valve complying with AWWA C500. Acceptable manufacturer Mueller model T-2360, with M.J. x FL. Ends. 
c.  Support the exposed existing water main on concrete pedestals at sufficient intervals to property carry its own weight, plus the weight of the tapping machinery and fittings. Provide thrust blocking. 
d.  Sanitize the portions of the tapping valve and sleeve that will be immediately exposed to the existing water supply. Open the tapping valve to flush any foreign material after completion of the pressure tapping. 
7.  Testing. 
a.  Pressure and leakage tests shall be conducted as follows: 
i.  A hydrostatic test shall be performed at 125 psi, for one hour, and must have zero loss. 
ii.  A hydrostatic test is to be performed at system pressure for twenty-four (24) hours. Maximum allowable loss is four gallons per inch of pipe diameter per one thousand (1,000) feet of pipe. RPZ backflow prevention devices must be utilized during filling/testing, and a village meter must be used for this test. 
b.  Chlorination and testing shall be accomplished and positively verified that the water system extension(s) have been disinfected and tested according to state and local approved standards and methods. Compliance with ANSI/AWWA C651-99 shall be considered the minimum requirement, in addition to any other procedures required by the village before placing into service. 
c.  Operation of existing system. No contractor or other person is authorized to operate valves or hydrants on the existing village system without permission from the director of public works. Employees of the village are the only people authorized to operate any portion of the village water system unless approved by the director or public works. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.604) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.20.060 - Street improvements. 
A.  Design. The design standards contained within the Table of Minimum Standards for Street Design shall apply to all streets. 
B.  Grading. The full width of the right-of-way shall be graded and erosion control measures installed as follows: 
1.  All stumps, trees that cannot be saved, boulders and similar items shall be removed. 
2.  Before any paving work is commenced, all street grading shall be properly completed as shown on the grading plan and approved by the village engineer. 
3.  All unsuitable sub-base material shall be removed and shall be replaced with stable, compacted material in conformance with generally accepted engineering practices and applicable village specifications. The determination of sub-base suitability shall be made by a method approved by the village engineer or consultant soils specialist/engineer. 
4.  After the grading of streets is completed and approved, and before any base course of the roadway pavement is laid, all of the underground work, such as water, sewer, and gas mains, house service connections therewith, and all underground conduits for electric, telephone or other franchise lines, shall be completely installed in place and approved. All installations shall be in conformance with the respective agreements established with the village or other state requirements. 
C.  Roadway Pavement. 
1.  All pavement thickness, including surface, base courses, and sub-base courses, shall be designed in accordance with either the Manual of Instructions for the Structural Design of Portland Cement Concrete Pavements, or Manual of Instructions for the Structural Design of Flexible Pavements involving MFT, FAS, and the current IDOT standards and specifications for road and bridge construction as applicable, and all subsequent revisions thereto, as published by the State of Illinois Department of Transportation. The minimum thickness for municipal streets shall be as specified therein. Design data shall be submitted to the village engineer together with copies of soil test reports, at the time of engineering plan submittal. 
2.  The procedure and calculation for street thicknesses shall follow subsection 1. (above). However, in no event shall pavement thicknesses be less than that established in the following table:

3.  The curb and gutter and the pavement structure shall be in place up to the binder course before building construction will be allowed. 
D.  Curbs and Gutters. 
1.  Curbs and gutters shall conform to the Illinois Division of Highways and village standards. Depressed type of entrance curbs having a width of not less than twelve (12) feet shall be provided at all private driveways. In the event the subdivider is unable to locate entrances at the time that the building permit is issued, a later scheduled cut with appropriate equipment and method, may be allowed with the approval of the village engineer. No curb drains shall be located in the path of driveways. All drains shall be located in nondriveway portions of single-family lots. 
2.  Unless otherwise specified, barrier curbs per village standards shall be required in residential, business, and industrial areas. Where required (See Section 16.20.070(A)(2)), a depressed type of curb shall be provided at all sidewalk ramps for the handicapped. All curbs shall receive a stamp imprint of "s" for sewer and "w" for water to mark the locations of such utility crossings. Two five-eighth-inch reinforcing bars (#5), ten (10) feet long, shall be installed in all curbs and gutters, centered over each sewer and water trench crossed by the curb and gutter. 
3.  Curb and gutter shall be placed on a minimum thickness of four inches of CA-6 aggregate base coarse, to match pavement base, but shall always be of such thickness that the bottom of the aggregate under the curb and gutter shall be of the same elevation as the bottom of the coarse aggregate under the adjacent pavement. The aggregate under the curb and gutter shall extend a minimum of twelve (12) inches in back of curb. 
E.  Storm Sewers. 
1.  Whenever curbs and gutters are required, underground storm sewers shall conform to the current Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois, current edition, Illinois Society of Professional Engineers, et al. and as set forth in the Manual of Highways Standards, Department of Transportation, State of Illinois, current editions. 
2.  At street sag locations with a curb and gutter inlet or catch basin, an under drain system shall be installed consisting of a four-inch perforated PVC pipe wrapped in filter fabric, installed within the twelve (12) inches of crushed stone required in back of the curb extending twenty-five (25) feet in each direction, longitudinal to the curb and gutter, and emptying into the inlet or catch basin. 
F.  Frontage Roads. The standards for construction of any frontage roads, providing access to property abutting a major arterial, shall be approved by the village, as recommended by the village engineer. 
G.  Erosion Control. All exposed surfaces within a street right-of-way and within the development shall be properly protected by rip rap, sod, seeding with rapid growing grass or vegetation, and ditch checks. All such work shall conform to the applicable provisions of the then current village watershed development ordinance (see Title 14 of this code), with a specific erosion control plan provided. Developer to follow all NPDES requirements and notifications. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.605) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.20.070 - Sidewalks, walkways, bikeways and green way corridors. 
A.  Sidewalks. 
1.  Sidewalks shall be located on both sides of the street, and shall be a minimum of four feet wide when located along cul-de-sacs, local streets, and collector streets, and shall be five feet wide when located along minor arterial streets and major arterial. The edge of such sidewalks shall be located one foot from the right-of-way line, unless the village board approves otherwise. 
2.  Sidewalks shall be not less than three inches above the center line of the street with a slope of the parkway between a minimum of two percent and a maximum of four percent, sloped toward the street. Sidewalks shall be constructed on a four (4) inch thick compacted CA-6, grade #9 gravel bedding. The sidewalk section shall be not less than five inches in thickness and thickened to six inches across the full width of the driveway. A construction joint groove shall be made at five-foot intervals. In the event the subdivider is unable to locate driveway entrances at the time of construction of sidewalks, the thickened sidewalk section shall be constructed from the side property lines to the third point of the lot frontage width. Sidewalk ramps for the handicapped shall be constructed in accordance with Standard 424001 of the Highway Standards, State of Illinois, current edition as shown in the village standard details. All sidewalks and sidewalk ramps must be constructed in conformance with the Americans With Disabilities Act and the Illinois Accessibility Code. 
3.  Expansion joints shall be installed in accordance with current village standards. 
B.  Walkways and Bikeways. Walkways and bikeways, not located in the street rights-of-way, shall be a minimum of eight (8) feet in width and may be constructed of bituminous materials and a stone base as recommended by the village engineer. 
C.  Greenway Corridors. Greenway corridors shall be constructed in new subdivisions in conformance with the comprehensive greenway corridor system of the village if applicable. The following types of corridors will be created: 
1.  Dual Purpose. These corridors will serve a dual purpose of pedestrian travel between points and recreational and leisure uses. Due to higher levels of use, these corridors shall be located in such a way to be more visible for public safety, emergency and police activities. There shall be a thirty-foot minimum dedicated corridor width and an eight-foot wide meandering asphalt path. In corridors along rights-of-way, additional landscaping shall be required. The landscaping plan must be approved by the village board. 
2.  Recreational. These corridors will serve as recreational and leisure facilities and will be located in such a way as to utilize the significant natural features of the area. There shall be a thirty-foot minimum corridor width, and path surfaces may be crushed limestone, boardwalks, or other surfaces suggested by the subdivider and approved by the village board. 
3.  The thirty-foot corridors may be used to determine the open space donation required by Section 16.16.100, and is to be maintained by the appropriate public agency. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.606) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.20.080 - Street lighting improvements. 
A.  General. 
1.  All development shall include the design and construction of street lighting facilities for the illumination of all roadways which lie in or border the development. The street lighting shall be in conformance with the standards and requirements established by the village engineer, in accordance with the provisions of the code, and subject to the approval of the corporate authorities of the village. It shall be the responsibility of the developer or subdivider to pay the installation cost of all such lighting. The street lighting system shall be guaranteed from the date of acceptance for a period of three years, except the street light pole assemblies and luminaires (lighting units) shall be guaranteed for five years. 
B.  Street lighting improvements shall be designed and installed in accordance with: 
1.  American National Standard Practice for Roadway Lighting (ANSI/IES RP-8 latest edition). 
2.  The National Electric Code (NEC, NFPA 70, latest edition). 
3.  District One Recurring Special Provisions for Highway Lighting (by IDOT, latest edition). 
4.  Local codes, ordinances, and development standards of the village. 
C.  Prior to the installation of any street lighting system, the following submittals are required for review and approval by the village: 
1.  Layout of the proposed street lighting system showing pole locations, right-of-way and any easements, cable routing, controller locations, mast arm orientation, mast arm length, and source of power. 
2.  Manufacturer's information on poles, luminaries, mast arms, unit duct, cable, conduit, handholes, controllers, and appurtenances. 
3.  Lighting calculations and design parameters. 
4.  Voltage drop calculations and electrical characteristics. 
5.  Circuit diagrams and schematics. 
D.  Street lighting installations in residential areas shall meet the following requirements: 
1.  Light pole assembly and luminaire (lighting unit) shall be as manufactured by Beacon Products. The lighting unit shall consist of a fluted case aluminum pole with accessories and either a single or double Mediterranean Series luminaire. The lighting unit shall have a verde green powder coat finish and be installed on a reinforced concrete foundation as per the standard details. 
a.  Luminaire shall be 60 Watt Direct LED, Type III distribution, catalog no. T1/AC/C1/H1/LED60-240-DIR3/FS/CC(Verde Green). 
b.  A single luminaire lighting unit shall consist of the specified luminaire mounted on a 14 foot pole. Lighting units shall be installed at intersections and at midblock locations. The lighting unit setback shall be a minimum of four feet from the face of the curb to the center of the unit, or as field conditions may dictate. Comply with Standard Detail No. L-1. 
c.  A double luminaire lighting unit shall consist of the specified luminaires mounted on a fourteen-foot pole forty (40) inches apart using an A522 series crossarm. Comply with Standard Detail No. L-3. Install lighting units in the center of the median of all boulevards. 
d.  Two single luminaire lighting units shall be installed on opposite corners at each intersection where two streets cross. One single luminaire lighting unit shall be installed at "T" intersections. The lighting unit shall be installed on the extended centerline of the street that terminates at the top of the "T". 
E.  Street lighting installations in commercial areas shall meet the following requirements: 
1.  Light pole assembly and luminaire (lighting unit) shall be as manufactured by Beacon Products. The lighting unit shall consist of a fluted case aluminum pole with accessories and either a single or double Mediterranean Series luminaire. The lighting unit shall have a verde green powder coat finish and be installed on a reinforced concrete foundation as per the standard details. 
a.  Luminaire shall be 60 Watt Direct LED, Type III distribution, catalog no. T1/AC/C1/H1/LED60-240-DIR3/FS/CC(Verde Green). 
b.  A single luminaire lighting unit shall consist of the specified luminaire mounted on a fourteen-foot pole. Lighting units shall be installed between intersections. The lighting unit setback shall be three feet from the face of the curb to the center of the unit, or as field conditions may dictate. Comply with Standard Detail L-2. 
F.  Provide to the village one spare lighting unit for every twenty (20) lighting units installed with a minimum of one unit per development. 
G.  All wiring installed for street lighting system from the power source to the lighting unit and from lighting unit to lighting unit, shall be provided with a bare ground wire and contained in unit duct manufactured from high density smooth wall polyethylene electrical plastic duct. Direct burial of all wire and cable in this section is prohibited. 
1.  Where wiring is routed under streets, driveways, sidewalks or other paved areas, the unit duct shall be installed in minimum two-inch diameter rigid steel conduit, large enough size to allow for an easy installation. If streets, driveways, sidewalks or other paved areas are existing the conduit shall be pushed. 
2.  All wiring installed for street lighting system shall be a minimum of No. 8 AWG and shall be heat and moisture resistant, Type XHHW, copper wire, and be suitable for use at 75 degrees C. (167 degrees F.) and shall have insulation rating of 600V. 
3.  All runs shall be continuous without splice in unit duct from light pole handhole to light pole handhole or to lighting controller. 
4.  All wiring shall be subject to an insulation test to ground after installation. The minimum acceptable resistance to ground shall be thirty (30) meg-ohms. Any section of wiring failing to pass the minimum insulation test for any reason shall be replaced. All circuits shall be tested in the presence of the village engineer. All unit duct shall be installed not less than thirty (30) inches below finish grade. 
H.  Lighting controller shall meet the following requirements: 
1.  An electrical service pedestal and weather proof disconnect switch shall be provided for lights connected directly to a utility transformer or pedestal located in the easement. 
2.  Electrical service connection to the utility supply from a lighting controller shall conform to the utility requirements and be installed by the developer. See Standard Detail L-5. 
3.  Where a lighting controller is required, provide a weatherproof enclosure, base mounted on a concrete foundation. The controller shall contain a main circuit breaker, lighting contractor(s), branch circuit breakers, control relays, H-O-A selector switch, duplex receptacle, and surge protection. See Standard Detail L-6 and L-7. 
I.  Grounding of the street lighting system shall be provided and tested as shown in the standard details and as follows: 
1.  All ground rods shall be subject to a resistance-to-earth test performed using the three-point method of measurement, or other means approved by the engineer. All ground rods shall be tested individually in the presence of the village engineer. The maximum D.C. resistance allowed shall be ten (10) ohms. If any ground rods fail, a second ground rod shall be driven ten (10) feet away from the first, connect both rods together and perform the test again if the resistance is still too high - additional rods may need to be installed. 
J.  Street lighting improvements in industrial areas shall be approved by the village board and shall conform to the following standards: 
1.  Metal standards shall be of one piece steel or aluminum construction with no extrusion or vertical butt welds and finished with hand hole openings covered flush with the pole surface. Shoe bases shall be welded to standards and shall be designed to permit fastening standards to a level foundation. 
2.  Standards shall be not less than thirty (30) feet nor greater than thirty-five (35) feet in height and bracket arms shall not be greater than twelve (12) feet. 
3.  Luminaries shall be two hundred fifty (250) to four hundred (400) watt high pressure sodium vapor, polycarbonate one piece injection molded with acrylic refractors, with an average life of three thousand (3,000) hours or more. 
K.  Electrical transmissions shall be underground, and shall be installed in conformance with the following standards. 
1.  The type shall be Copper Stranded 600 Volt in PVC conduit (uniduct). 
2.  The size shall be: 
a.  Minimum No. 6 wire for multiple service; 
b.  Minimum No. 8 wire for individual service. 
3.  The minimum trench depth shall be two feet six inches. 
4.  At street crossings, the wire shall be in PVC conduit in minimum two-inch diameter galvanized steel conduit. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.607) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.20.090 - Street signs/pavement striping. 
A.  Street name signs shall be fabricated of aluminum or other approved noncorrosive material to the following dimensions: 
1.  The length shall be twenty-four (24) inches, unless the street name requires a greater length. 
2.  The width shall be nine inches, as measured from the edge of the sign to the edge of the sign and not from tile edge of the reflective boarder to the edge of the reflective border. 
3.  All street signs shall be fabricated to a thickness of one-sixteenth inch, plus or minus. 
B.  The street signs shall be reflectorized and shall have a white legend on a green background: 
C.  Lettering of the street names shall be at least six inches high. Supplemental lettering to indicate the type of street or section of the village may be in smaller lettering but shall be at least four inches high. Conventional abbreviations shall be acceptable, except for the street name itself. 
D.  Street signs shall be mounted parallel to the streets they name and shall be at least seven feet high, as measured from the top of the curb on curbed street, or from the edge of pavement on all others. They shall be positioned so that they are two feet back from the face of the curb on curbed streets and two feet back from the edge of the pavement on all other streets. 
E.  Street signs shall be mounted on street lighting poles where practical. Otherwise, they shall be mounted on two-inch diameter galvanized steel pipe painted black and embedded two feet below ground surface in concrete. The thickness of the concrete shall be at least six inches from the exterior of the pipe, and it shall be cast against the surrounding soil. 
F.  All brackets, screws, and other appurtenances used to fasten street signs to supporting poles shall be of galvanized steel, stainless steel, or other approved noncorrosive material. 
G.  Pavement striping for stop bars, pedestrian/school/bikeway crosswalks, lane markings or center line striping shall be installed in reflective thermoplastic or epoxy paint at the discretion of the village in accordance with IDOT specifications. 
H.  Regulatory and warning traffic control signs are to be furnished and installed by the developer in accordance with the approved final engineering plans, and as directed by the village public works department. Sign size, reflectivity, and methods of mounting shall meet village standards. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.608) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.20.100 - Mailboxes. 
A.  When required by federal rules and regulations for mail delivery, a single mailbox per residence or commercial property may be installed within the public right-of-way under the jurisdiction of the village, subject to the conditions contained in this section. 
B.  The mailbox shall be installed off of the pavement surface so that the bottom of the mailbox is forty-two (42) inches above the driveable surface; and the front face of the mailbox is no closer than eight inches to the pavement's edge, and no farther than ten (10) inches from the pavement's edge, or installed at a height and distance from the pavement's edge as is consistent with applicable federal regulations as they exist from time to time. 
C.  The mailbox shall be mounted on a wooden post support structure which is a minimum of four inches by four inches or a maximum of six inches by six inches, or a minimum of one and one-half inch to a maximum of three-inch diameter light gauge hollow pipe, or on such other similar structure as is approved by the village building inspector, and found by the village building inspector to be of comparable safety to the wooden post or light gauge pipe structures. Other support structures including, but not limited to, masonry columns, railroad rails and ties, tractor wheels, plow blades, milk cans, or barrels filled with concrete, are expressly prohibited. 
D.  The support structure shall be firmly secured in the ground. 
E.  The posts shall be set back two feet six inches from the back of the curb on curbed streets and two feet six inches from the edge of the pavement on all other streets. 
F.  The mailbox door shall be set back six to eight inches from the front face of the curb or road edge. 
G.  The bottom of the mailbox shall be forty-two (42) to forty-six (46) inches from the road surface. 
H.  Any additional construction specifications as are necessary to implement these standards shall be published by the village community development department. 
I.  Mailboxes shall be clustered in cul-de-sacs. 
J.  Different mailbox posts than specified in this section may be installed to conform to the architectural intent of the surrounding buildings as recommended by the plan commission and approved by the village board. 
K.  Mailboxes shall be installed on the same side of the street as the hydrants on the water distribution system. They shall be ganged in groups of three or four at every other lot line unless approved otherwise. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.609) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012; Ord. No. 18-O-21, § 7, 5-21-2018) 
Chapter 16.24 - OTHER CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS 
Sections: 

16.24.010 - Soil investigations. 
A.  If the subdivision contains questionable soil or areas are discovered in the course of construction, and in the opinion of the village engineer soil investigations, borings or other soil tests are necessary to determine the nature and extent of such questionable material, the owner or subdivider shall retain or cause to be retained the services of a competent testing laboratory to perform the needed investigations. 
B.  Copies of the completed reports prepared by the testing laboratory and sealed by an Illinois-licensed professional engineer shall be filed with the village. 
C.  The village shall have no liability for costs connected with the tests, borings or interpretations or results of such work. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.701) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.24.020 - Blasting. 
    No blasting shall take place in connection with any work in a subdivision until appropriate village authorities have been notified and the applicable village ordinances complied with. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.702) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.24.030 - Inspection. 
A.  All public improvements proposed to be made under the provisions of this title shall be inspected during the course of construction by the village. 
B.  During the course of construction of the improvements, the subdivider shall be required to notify the village forty-eight (48) hours before work commences, and before work resumes after a hiatus. 
C.  The subdivider shall pay the cost of all inspection services to the village. The fee shall be established by the village, based on current rates and standard engineering practices and will be deposited in an escrow amount held by the village before work begins. 
    The subdivider shall pay a fee of one percent of the total cost of the required public improvements for administrative expenses related to the development. Said fee shall be in addition to the inspection escrow established. The fee shall be paid upon approval of the final plat. No construction may begin, nor any permits issued, until this fee has been paid to the village. 
D.  The general inspection periods or visit by the village shall be as follows, or as modified by the village:

(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.703)

16.24.040 - Qualifications of contractors. 
    The subdivider shall file with the village a list of all contractors and subcontractors who are to participate in the construction of public improvements. Such contractors and subcontractors shall be subject to disqualification by reason of faulty performance or prior poor construction work history done in the village. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.704) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.24.050 - Sequence of construction. 
    No underground utilities or storm sewers, except inlet drains, shall be installed under the pavement in streets, alleys, service roads, or highways. Service connections to such underground utilities and sewers shall be extended to the property line of each lot so as to obviate disturbing the surface improvements in such public ways when service connections are later made. Where underground utilities are located in the parkway adjacent to a paved roadway, service connections to properties across such roadway shall only be made by drilling under the pavement in such a way that surfacing is not disturbed or weakened, and excavation shall be compacted with granular backfill and properly restored. The current Illinois Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction, latest edition shall apply. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.705) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.24.060 - Debris removal. 
    The subdivider shall clean and maintain all public ways, sewers, and drains free from debris, trash or other extraneous material, during construction to prevent the creation of a public nuisance. All such public ways, sewers and drains shall be cleaned of all debris, trash or other extraneous material prior to acceptance by the village. Storm sewer systems are to be checked as per the WDO. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.706) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.24.070 - Modifications of design of improvements during construction. 
    During the course of inspections, the appropriate public inspector will especially note any circumstances which necessitate departures from the plans and specifications for the improvements, as approved, including but not limited to, an unforeseen difficulty in drainage, ground water, poor subsoil, unstable fill material, or unconventional or faulty practices of subcontractors. Whenever such departures are likely to cause a lower ultimate level of performance than could reasonably have been anticipated, the inspector shall prepare a report of his or her findings of the situation and promptly forward copies to the village for appropriate action. If this faulty work involves work that can easily be removed from view, such as underground work, the inspector may issue a written stop order to have all work activities involving the faulty work cease till further notice. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.707) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.24.080 - Safety. 
    The subdivider, or any contractors or sub-contractors are obligated to conduct any construction operations with safety to the public as a paramount priority. Any operations requiring the operation of equipment, excavations, or any other hazardous operation shall include all necessary signs/barricades/fencing or any other necessary safety measures to protect workers or the public. All responsibility for implementing such measures shall rest with the subdivider or his contractors, not the village or its agents. 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
Chapter 16.28 - LAND DEDICATIONS 
Sections: 

16.28.010 - Land dedications. 
A.  Dedication by Irrevocable Offer to Dedicate. Dedication of all land, easements and rights-of-way to the public shall be shown and indicated on the final plat, which shall be accompanied by an irrevocable offer to dedicate the land, which offer shall be filed at the office of the recorder of deeds. 
B.  Acceptance by Village. Acceptance of such dedicated land easements or rights-of-way shall be by action of the village board and shall be by warranty deed. Subdividers shall present evidence of good title through a title insurance policy issued by a reputable company, dated within one year of the dedication. 
    Lands covered by this section include, but are not limited to: streets, rights-of-way, park sites, trails and greenways, storm water detention areas and wetlands, school sites and municipal sites. 
    Prior to the conveyance of land, the subdivider, or grantor, shall furnish to the village, or other appropriate governing authority, the following: 
1.  Certification that soils are free of all noxious or toxic chemical matter, as defined by the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency; 
2.  Certification that soils are free of unsuitable fill materials, including, but not limited to: construction or demolition debris; excessive quantities of trees, roots and other vegetable matter; discarded household or machinery items and unstable soils; 
3.  The certification shall be prepared by a recognized firm, specializing in environmental investigations. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.801) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
Chapter 16.32 - VACATIONS 
Sections: 

16.32.010 - Procedure. 
    In all cases, the vacation of any plat, or part thereof, or any public right-of-way, easement or part thereof, shall follow the procedure for the review of plats established in the subdivision regulations except: 
A.  Final action shall be taken by the village board after consultation with the plan commission. 
B.  The enforcing officer shall recommend to the village board a sum to be paid by the owner(s) of abutting properties in consideration of any public property involved in the vacation. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.901) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.32.020 - Standard. 
    The plan commission and the other administrative officers shall recommend disapproval of any petition for vacation which fails to meet the following standards: 
A.  No vacation shall be approved which creates a condition which would not be permitted under the standards of design set forth herein unless such vacation will, at the same time, correct a more serious condition which exists contrary to the standards of this title. 
B.  No vacation shall be approved which will result in a violation of Title 17 or other applicable ordinances or regulations, unless such vacation will, at the same time, correct a more serious condition which exists contrary to such ordinances or regulations. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.902) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.32.030 - Petition form and content. 
    The preliminary plat of vacation shall be accompanied by a certified statement of the assessed valuation of all properties surrounding any public right-of-way to be vacated. Final petitions for vacation shall include the following items: 
A.  Three copies of the original plat certified by the county recorder of deeds to be a true copy of the same, on which is shown the portion to be vacated outlined in a heavy line and hatched. 
B.  The following deeds, petitions and certificates: 
1.  Deed of vacation; 
2.  Petition, three copies; 
3.  County clerk's certificate; 
4.  Resolution or ordinance; 
5.  Assessor's certificate. 
C.  The petition as it is presented to the village board shall be accompanied by a recommendation from the plan commission. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.903) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.32.040 - Easements. 
    The vacation of any plat, or part thereof, or right-of-way, easement, or part thereof, shall not be deemed to be a vacation of the rights of any public utility where the public utility has installed its facilities therein. All such vacations shall be made upon the express condition that the abutting property owner(s) grant to all public utilities, their successors and assigns, the right-of-way or easement to operate, maintain, renew and reconstruct their facilities, over, or under the public right-of-way or easement vacated and such condition shall be noted in the deed or plat of vacation and in the ordinance or resolution of vacation. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.904) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.32.050 - Bonds. 
    The village may require the petitioner to furnish a bond or other security in an amount determined by the village sufficient to protect the village and to indemnify it for any suit which may be filed for damages sustained as a result of such vacation. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.905) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.32.060 - Limitation. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter, nor any required certificate, shall be deemed in any way to limit the right and authority of the village to vacate any plat or part thereof, or any right-of-way or easement or part thereof where it finds that such vacation will serve the public interest. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.906) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.32.070 - Resubdivision in lieu of vacation. 
    It shall not be necessary to vacate a plat or part thereof in order to proceed with a resubdivision of a plat or part thereof. Resubdivision according to the procedure and standards for subdivision required by this title shall automatically constitute vacation of a prior plat or part thereof, provided that monetary remuneration shall be paid to the village in consideration of any excess public property vacated over that dedicated in the subdivision. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.907) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.32.080 - Cancellation of bonded contracts. 
    Bonded contracts for the improvements of platted streets or alleys shall be automatically cancelled upon vacation of such platted streets or alleys. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.908) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
Chapter 16.36 - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
Sections: 

16.36.010 - Amendments. 
A.  Action by the Plan Commission. 
1.  The plan commission or village board on its own motion shall consider any proposed changes and amendments to the regulations contained in this title. 
2.  The plan commission may, on its own motion, call a public hearing on the proposed changes or amendments. 
3.  The plan commission shall forward the proposed changes or amendments, with its recommendation, to the village board for appropriate action. 
B.  Action by Village Board. The village board, after reviewing the proposed changes and the recommendation of the plan commission shall: 
1.  Adopt the proposed changes or amendments; 
2.  Deny the proposed changes or amendments; 
3.  Submit the changes or amendments to the plan commission for further analysis and review. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.1001) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.36.020 - Variances. 
    The plan commission may recommend variances from the requirements of this title in specific cases which, in its opinion, do not adversely affect the comprehensive plan or the intent of this title. Such recommendations shall be communicated to the appropriate body, either the village board or governing county authorities, in writing, substantiating the recommended variance. The village board may approve variations from the requirements of this title when, in its opinion, such variations will not adversely affect the comprehensive plan or the intent of this title. The village board shall not approve variations that result in requirements less than required by the Lake County subdivision regulations ordinance for subdivisions located in the unincorporated areas under the extraterritorial jurisdiction of this title. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.1002) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.36.030 - Appeals. 
A.  Any person aggrieved by a decision of the plan commission and/or enforcing officer in enforcing the terms of this title may request a hearing before the village board. Requests for such hearings shall be made in writing to the enforcing officer, who shall schedule an appointment for a hearing before the village board within thirty (30) days following receipt of any such request. 
B.  If, upon the evidence presented by the plan commission, and the enforcing officer, and the evidence presented by the petitioner, the village board finds that the decision of the plan commission or enforcing officer is in error, the village board may require the plan commission or enforcing officer to modify its decision. Such modification shall not conflict with this title. The decision of the village board shall be made known in writing to the petitioner within thirty (30) days of the hearing. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.1003) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.36.040 - Planned unit development. 
    The provision of this title may be waived for a planned unit development, as approved by the village board; provided, that all requirements of the planned unit development section of the Round Lake zoning ordinance (see Chapter 17.80) have been complied with. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.1100) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.36.050 - Enforcement. 
A.  No plat of any subdivision shall be entitled to be recorded in the recorder's office or have any validity unless and until it shall have been approved in the manner prescribed in this title. The enforcing officer whose duty it is to enforce the provisions whereof may call upon any department or official of the village to furnish the officer with such information and assistance as may be deemed necessary for the observance or enforcement of this title. It shall be the duty of such department or officer to furnish such information and assistance whenever required. 
B.  Public utilities shall obtain permits from the village board for the installation of communication, electric power, gas, or other utility services before any installation is started. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.1201) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012) 
16.36.060 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  Any person, firm or corporation who is found guilty of constructing any public improvement or portion thereof in violations of the provision of this title or violating any other requirement of the zoning ordinance shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense plus the costs of the action and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
B.  Any person, firm or corporation who is found guilty of selling or offering for sale, lease or offer for lease, while this title is in effect any lot or lots or block or blocks, within the incorporated limits of the village, or any resubdivision of any lot or block therein, or within contiguous territory and not more than one and one-half miles beyond the incorporated boundary of the village, before a final plat of subdivision has been approved by the plan commission and the village board as required by this title unless it meets the exceptions contained in the Plat Act (765 ILCS 205.01), shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each lot, block or part thereof so disposed of or offered for sale or leased. 
(Ord. 99-O-29 § 1 (part): prior code § 22.1202) 
(Ord. No. 12-O-25, § 1(Exh. A), 11-5-2012)

Title 17 - ZONING 
Chapters: 
Chapter 17.04 - INTRODUCTORY PROVISIONS AND DEFINITIONS 
Sections: 

17.04.010 - Short title. 
    This title shall be known, cited and referred to as the comprehensive amendment to the Round Lake zoning ordinance, hereinafter referred to as the "Round Lake zoning ordinance." 
(Zoning ord. Art. I) 
17.04.020 - Intent and purpose. 
    This zoning ordinance is adopted for the purpose of improving and protecting the public health, safety, comfort, convenience, and general welfare of the people. The fulfillment of this purpose is to be accomplished by seeking the following objectives: 
A.  To limit congestion in the public streets and to protect the public health, safety, convenience and general welfare, by providing for the off-street parking of motor vehicles and the loading and unloading of commercial vehicles; 
B.  To prevent the overcrowding of land and undue concentration of structures in each zoning district, thereby ensuring proper living and working conditions and preventing the development of blight and slums; 
C.  To provide adequate light, pure air, privacy and convenience of access to property; 
D.  To facilitate the provision of adequate transportation, and of other public requirements and service such as water, sewage, schools and parks; 
E.  To conserve the value of property throughout the village and to protect the character and stability of residential, business and industrial areas; 
F.  To provide for the gradual elimination of nonconforming uses of land, buildings and structures which would adversely affect the character and value of structures and neighborhoods; 
G.  To divide the village into districts of such number, shape, area, and of such different classes, according to the use of land, buildings, the height, and bulk of buildings, the intensity of use, and the area of open spaces and recreational spaces, as may be deemed best suited to carry out the purposes of this title; 
H.  To lessen or avoid the hazard to persons and damage to property resulting from the accumulation of run-off or storm or flood waters; 
I.  To preserve and insure the preservation of natural resources; 
J.  To preserve and insure the preservation of acres of historical and architectural significance; 
K.  To prevent the overcrowding of land and undue concentration of structure, so far as is possible and appropriate in each district, by regulating the use and bulk of buildings in relation to the land surrounding them; 
L.  To conserve the taxable value of land and buildings throughout the village; 
M.  To avoid the inappropriate development of lands and provide for adequate drainage, curbing of erosion, and reduction of flood damage; 
N.  To fix reasonable standards to which buildings and structures shall conform; 
O.  To prevent such additions to, and alterations or remodeling of, existing buildings or structures as would not comply with the restrictions and limitations imposed in this title; 
P.  To foster a more rational pattern of relationship between residential, business, commercial and manufacturing uses for the mutual benefit of all; 
Q.  To isolate or control the location of unavoidable nuisance producing uses, and to protect against fire, explosion, noxious fumes, and other dangers; 
R.  To define the powers and duties of the administrative and enforcement officers and bodies; 
S.  To prescribe penalties for any violation of the provisions of this title, or of any amendment thereto. 
    The standards and requirements contained in this title, and the district mapping reflected on the Round Lake zoning district map, are intended to implement the objectives of the comprehensive plan for the village. 
(Zoning ord. Art. II) 
17.04.030 - Contradictory regulations. 
    Where any contradictory regulations, restrictions or requirements imposed by any provision of this title upon the use of any land, building, structures or improvements are either more restrictive or less restrictive than restrictions or requirements imposed by any other provision of this title or any other law of any governmental body having jurisdiction over the subject matter thereof, those restrictions or requirements which are more restrictive shall govern. 
(Zoning ord. § 13.1) 
17.04.040 - Rules and definitions. 
    In the construction of this title and any subsequent amendment, the rules and definitions contained in this section shall be observed and applied, except when the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
A.  Rules. 
1.  Words used in the present tense shall include the future. 
2.  Words used in the singular number shall include the plural number, and the plural singular. 
3.  The word "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary. 
4.  The word "may" is permissive. 
5.  The word "lot" shall include the words "piece" and "parcel." 
6.  The word "building" shall include the word "structure" and shall include all other improvements of every kind regardless of similarity to buildings. 
7.  The phrase "used for" shall include the phrases "arranged for," designed for," "intended for," "maintained for," and "occupied for." 
8.  The word "person" shall include a "firm, association, organization, partnership, trust, company, or corporation as well as an individual." 
9.  The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter. 
B.  Definitions. The following words and terms shall have the meaning set forth, except where otherwise specifically indicated. Words and terms not defined shall have the meaning indicated by common dictionary definition. 
    "Agriculture" means land including necessary buildings and structures, for the raising of soil crops or the raising of domestic animals as the principal occupation of the residents or users thereof. It shall also include truck-farming, beekeeping, the raising of fruit and berries, and selling the products thereof, but shall not include the feeding of garbage to animals. 
    "Airport" means an area of land or water which is used or intended for use for the landing and taking-off of aircraft, and any appurtenant areas which are used or intended for use for airport buildings or other airport facilities or rights-of-ways, including all necessary taxiway, aircraft storage and tie down areas, hangars and other necessary buildings and open spaces. 
    "Alley" means a dedicated public right-of-way, other than a street, that affords a secondary means of access to abutting property. 
    "Alterations" means any change in size, shape, character, occupancy, or use of a building or structure. 
    "Animal hospital" means a structure or portion thereof, designed or used for the care, observation or treatment of domestic animals. 
    "Apartment" means a room or suite of rooms in a multiple dwelling suitable for occupancy by an individual, group or individuals or a family. 
    "Apartment hotel" means a building designed or utilized for residential hotel accommodations by permanent guests. 
    "Apparel stores" means stores selling new clothing for men, women or children at retail. 
    "Appliance sales" means the sales of common household appliances such as washing machines, television sets, power tools, electric razors, radios and refrigerators, and repair of the same types of appliances as are sold on the premises when such repairs are incidental or accessory to their sale. 
    "Auto court" means the same as motel. (See "Motel.") 
    "Automobile accessory store" means a store engaged primarily in the business of selling tires, batteries, seat covers, and other automobile accessories. 
    "Automobile laundry" means a building or portion thereof containing facilities for washing more than two vehicles, using automatic production-line methods with a chain conveyor, blower, steam cleaning device, or other mechanical devices; or providing space, water and equipment for the hand washing of automobile whether by the customer or the operator. 
    "Automobile repair" means general repair, overall painting, engine repairing or rebuilding, reconditioning of motor vehicles, trailers such as body or frame work, and fender straightening. 
    "Automobile sales" means the sale of new and used automobile and other motor vehicles in operating condition; the storage of automobiles and other motor vehicles in operating condition, but not including storage of trucks of more than five tons in weight or buses; and, the repair and servicing of such vehicles, including body work, painting, motor rebuilding, where conducted within a completely enclosed building. 
    "Automobile service station" means a building or portion thereof, or lot used for offering for sale at retail to the public, fuels, oils and accessories for motor vehicles; where repair service is incidental, where no storage or parking space is offered for sale or rent. 
    "Automobile trailer" means any vehicle, without motor power, used or so constructed as to permit it being used as a conveyance upon the public streets and highway and licensable as such, constructed in such a manner as will permit occupancy as a dwelling or sleeping place for one or more persons, and including also a self propelled vehicle having body designed as living quarters. 
    "Automobile wrecking" means the dismantling of used motor vehicles or trailers, the burning of combustible parts thereof, or the storage, sale or dumping of dismantled or wrecked motor vehicles or their parts. 
    "Awning" means a roof-like cover that is temporary in nature and that projects from the wall of a building for the purpose of shielding a doorway or window from the elements. 
    "Banks and financial institutions" means commercial banks, savings and loan associations, brokage offices and other similar financial institutions, but not including pawn shops. 
    "Basement" means that portion of a building having more than one-half of its height below the average lot grade. 
    "Block" means a tract of land bounded by streets, or by a combination of streets and public parks, cemeteries, bulkhead lines, or shore lines of waterways, or corporate lines of the village. 
    "Boundary house" means a building, other than a hotel, where meals for three or more persons, and not to exceed twenty (20) persons are served for compensation to regular patrons by previous arrangement. If a number greater than twenty (20) are regularly served, the establishment shall be classified as a restaurant. Rest homes, nursing homes, homes for the aged, homes for children and penal institutions shall not be classified as boarding homes. 
    "Building" means a permanently located, roofed, structure designed or intended for the enclosure, shelter or protection of persons, animals or moveable property of any kind and which is permanently affixed to the land. 
    "Building height" means the vertical distance measured from the sidewalk level of its equivalent established grade opposite the middle of the front of the building to the highest elevation of the roof in the case of a slant or flat roof; to the deck line of a mansard roof; and to the mean height level between eaves and ridge of a gable, chip or gamlerel roof; provided that where buildings are set back from the street lines, the height of the building may be measured from the average elevation of the finished lot grade at the front of the building. 
    "Building line" means the line nearest the front of and across a zoning lot, establishing the minimum open space to be provided between the front line of a building or structure and the street right-of-way line. 
    Building, Principal. "Principal building" means a nonaccessory building in which a principal use of the lot, on which it is located, is conducted. 
    "Bulk" means the term used to indicate the gross floor area of a building in relation to the lot area, the height of the structure, and the percentage of land coverage allowable for each building on a zoning lot. 
    "Business and professional office" means the office of an engineer, doctor, dentist, attorney, real estate broker, architect, or other similar professional person, and any office used primarily for accounting, correspondence, research, editing or administration. 
    "Business district" means any zoning district designated with a "C" classification. 
    "Capacity in persons" means the maximum number of persons that can avail themselves of service (or goods) of an establishment, at any one time, with reasonable comfort. 
    "Carport" means an open sided, roofed automobile shelter, usually formed by extension of the roof from the side of the building. 
    Club, Private (Nonprofit). "Private (nonprofit) club" means a nonprofit association of persons, who are bona fide members paying annual dues, which owns, hires or leases a building or portion thereof, the use of such premises being restricted to members and their guests. The affairs and management of such private club are conducted by a board of directors, executive committee, or similar body chosen by the members. It shall be permissible to serve food and meals on the premises, providing adequate dining room space and kitchen facilities are available. The sale of alcoholic beverages to members and their guests shall be subject to compliance with the village, state and federal ordinances.
